Is the Taj Mahal beautiful , absolutely . Is it also terribly managed and a mess , absolutely . The city of Agra is absolutely disgusting , and clearly none of the money that is paid by visitors by the Taj does not go back into the town of Agra , or even to keeping up the Taj . When we visited , we left our hotel well before sunrise to arrive at the gates and ensure that we were one of the firt groups to arrive . It was already packed , and we did not visit in tourist season . On the walk to the ticket office , we walked by more trash than I have seen in India ( I have been here many many times , and even this amount was appalling ) beggars , and all different species of animals that were running wild and very poorly cared for . The most suprising were the horses that were giving people rides to the Taj , they were stick thin , and were clearly overused and abused , and not well fed or cared for . It was surprising that we could not drive up to the gates , but the reasoning was because the pollution was staining the Taj . But yet , you could drive up within .25 km of the monument itself , and immediately outside the gates were cars , and trash . The ban on cars was absolutely non-sensical . The beggars were bold and refused to hear a no from me , it required my male coworker to tell them no . Same goes for the hawkers running alongside us trying to sell us tiny chess sets and magnets . By the time we got in line , we were exhausted , overstimulated , and ready to leave . We waited in line for a long time to get through the laughable security , while monkeys on top of the building hooted and jumped around , and literally defecated on top of the awnings we were under . I know you cannot control monkeys , but there is nothing that can be done to prevent this experience ? Once we got inside , the building was breathtaking , for a minute . And then the insta-tourists revealed themselves , with their hair flips , hats , selfie sticks and hand holding poses . It actually took so long for us to move to the front of the queue of people trying to take photos with selfie sticks , it became more entertaining to watch them fight about who was going to get their selfie first . As we walked up to go into the mausoleam we had to put on booties over our shoes , which I am in support of . The monument should be treated as a wonder of the world . Unfortunately that is where the thoughfulness ended . As we walked up , the carpets were haphazardly laying around , halfway rolled up and causing the site to look like a mess , and preventing people from walking on them . Looking out over the river in the back is also an eye opening experience , as the trash that is piled up in back of the site is appalling , as is the trash floating down the river . Also , all the pools were empty , and very very dirty . And , no exaggeration , there are dead pigeons on the ledges inside the mausoleum . Does anyone give a hoot about this place ? Ultimately , it is a beautiful place , that will continue to be run down if the mis-management continues , and will spiral quickly as the tourists increase . I am not sure where the money from ticket sales go , but it clearly is not going to maintenance , cleaning or damages prevention .

Taj Mahal is my dream place of visit because I read about it since childhood . However , I was disappointed to arrive at a poorly poorly managed location with haze ( from air pollution ) that photos can hardly be clear . Rusty pipes in the pond greets visitors as well as eroded plaques in many places . The worst part is that they charge tourists significantly higher price to enter , as compared to locals . The haze that surrounded the whole region is caused by burning of harvested land hence it can not be cleared in a few weeks . Breathing is difficult as well as allergies , coughing and eyes irritation makes the entire trip miserable . The pictures displayed is not what you get . If you really want to see this piece of history , go prepared with masks , allergy medicine and of course a huge purse . Yes , my most unforgetable / embarrassing experience is being harrassed by the toilet cleaner because I did not have 1 rupee to pay for my toilet visit . When I change money , they give big notes in rupees . Otherwise I only have euros and USD in hundreds . Toilet visits and shoes deposits cost small money BUT they DO NOT give change . Wait for your shoes to disappear , do it on the grass or make sure you have small change . Overall visit is unpleasant despite having to pay exorbitant prices for small gifts because they are trained to add a few more zeros to the back of ticketed items and deny that the tag on that item is the price for locals .

review_body: Our long awaited visit to the magnificent and beautiful Taj Mahal with an excellent and informative guide was truly ruined by seeing the condition of the starved , weak horses slipping and stumbling as they tried to pull the tourist laden Tonga carts on the totality unsuitable marble road surface leading to the front gate . We understand that in India most of the animals are slim and have work to do and we were generally impressed with how the animals were looked after in Rajasthan , however the condition of the horses and donkeys pulling these carts in Agra was very distressing and completely ruined our experience and memories of our visit to the Taj Mahal . Please DO NOT encourage this cruelty and inform your tour operator BEFORE you visit because if you just refuse the ride on the day , the guide and the horse owner will have already been paid . We were too distressed to take photographs of the terrible condition of these horses which we now regret as most also had sores from the harnesses and looked completely emaciated ! The short walk along the marble road is only a few minutes but if it is too far there are plenty of rickshaws which are far more suitable and ultimately will make for a more enjoyable overall experience .

I never wrote a review for my first trip but decided it was necessary for this trip . If you are going with a large guided trip then this may not apply to you but as a small group driving your own car , read on . Firstly , get there as EARLY as possible , the crowd explodes around noon and it is not even pleasant near that time for walking inside the Taj Mahal itself . it is 100 rupees to park at the east or west car park , since the entire area is based on symmetry , they are exactly alike and just go to the one closest for you . You will instantaneously be picked up in the park by a team consisting of an electric bike with driver , and a tour guide . They will take you directly to the Taj Mahal entrance from your car if you so choose , for 100-150 rupees . While on the ride , the tour guide will offer you his services and show you his guide ID card with two different prices , one for Indian and one for foreigners 1,200 , and 2,275 rupees respectively . He will likely offer you the Indian price if you are hesitant , and pretty much force you into buying his services . If it is at peak hours , he really will get you through all of the lines quickly but his pitch about the lower price is a flat out lie and when it comes time to pay he will still charge foreigners price and expect a tip for the VIP package . Both times I went I had that exact scenario . The ticket for entry is 1,000 rupees for North Americans , Australians and Europeans , 550 for Asian and South Americans . Plus 10 rupees per person for shoe covers and a bottle of water . You will then proceed to the Royal Gate and have a little story time outside , then go up to the gate for photos , where you will be swarmed with that tour guides photographer friends to sell you their services , and I mean hounded , then upon entering the courtyard you will again be hounded by photographers every step of the way until about midway to Taj Mahal itself . Up to you if you want it , they give photos in a decent little album after your tour is done , also on CD or USB for varying prices starting near 2,000 rupees . Congratulations , you have made it through the hustlers , for now . But inside the Taj Mahal there will be a security guy on the other side of the fence , he will show you how the marble looks with a flashlight and shout your name so you can hear the echo , then he will expect a small tip for his services , we gave 10 rupees and he was okay with it . After finishing the inside tour , hearing the history and seeing the incredible craftsmanship , which is what you actually came for , including the guest house and mosque , the really negative things begin . The tour guide will immediately begin talking up the 17 generations of craftsmen , this is all to get you interested in their sales , which will be friends of his that he has colluded with to make sales . You will depart through a side gate into the workers colony , which is beyond sketchy ( keep you hand on your wallet and phone pockets at all times here ) . The ATM is conveniently located right out the gate and amid hundreds of people from ages 4 to 104 shouting at you to buy their cups or fridge magnets . This is the art of the tour I tried to avoid the second time but the tour guide will have nothing of the sort . He will take you to a shop where they will try to sell you many things made from marble and pretty stones , which are very nice but I paid 100 US dollars for a 2 inch elephant , after haggling . The prices are absolutely unbelievably high . After leaving the shops things get even more sketchy as the route is full of twists , turns and suspicious looking guys pretending to talk on phones while watching your every more , do not stop , do not talk , just go back to your car . After the exit you will arrive right back at the ticket area and will need to buy another ride back to the car park , and pay your guide . When you get back to the car park the hustlers will try everything in their power to get you to buy ANYTHING , all the way to the car , and at your window . Probably a good time to mention that if you parked in an actual parking space , by now you are very likely boxed in by a parallel parked car , which may or may not be in neutral for you to move it and depart . For us it was luckily the former . All in all the place is lovely . But , the hustlers and hagglers , and general pushiness of everyone to get you to buy extras made us extremely frustrated on both ends of the tour . Outside the Taj Mahal afterwards feels like you are swimming in chummed water during Shark Week , and completely ruins the experience .
Too busy one of those awful experience of something so famous but not really wort it would not recommend to anyone very tiring .

On the whole , India has had more disappointing moments than good vibes , As a South African , when I see tourists or have guests , I try to personally help them have a good time . Thankfully , for tourists in sunny SA , that is usually easy to do . Tourists to SA pay the same for services , taxis and experiences as our locals and thankfully , rip-offs are rare . they are also made to feel welcome - you would want them to come back . I am grateful for my experiences and senses here in India nonetheless . Somewhat of a if you have not travelled to India , you have not REALLY travelled-scenario . Perhaps I have high standards and yes , this has been the cheapest holiday ever in terms of food and transport ( even with the numerous unwanted tourist rate hikes but cleanliness and pollution is a bigger negative to India . If I were at a different lifestage , pehaps Id feel different . India never made it onto my travel bucketlist until a good friends wedding invite for her wedding . Then we were told less than a month before our departure that she would not be coming to India after-all , so the reunion plans were also cancelled . We changed our internal flights ( at a fee ) from Amritsar to spend more time in Delhi and Goa , rather than losing more money by cancelling flights and accommodation or being stuck in rural India where the wedding would have been , for 10 days . From day one , the trip became a love / hate expedition . Five days in , until the 2nd day in Goa , it felt more like hard work than a holiday . The scams , haggling and different treatment of tourists - as cash cows - led to a repeated bitter taste compared to the fewer positives ( the food in Delhi was probably of the most flavoursome I have eaten ) . Safe to say that I will not be back in India in a hurry . Not even for a good curry . Even if the postponed wedding becomes a reality . What were the positives - The food and our 5 - star Delhi hotel for the first part of our trip being the two main highlights , there were a few moments like seeing the Taj Mahal and having sundowners with awesome friends on Goan shores that were great . But all the positives except the Taj can be found in other ( more relaxing and cleaner ) holiday destinations . Yes , our pictures are amazing ! We had some great sundowners and lovely sunsets . But often the behind-the-scenes work in creating those positive images were less glamorous . Like the chaos before entering the Taj Mahal with queues , ticket touts , persistent shopkeepers and signage saying that there are free lockers inside the monument , only to be told at the security scanners it is not true - that the guards will confiscate your snacks , books and JBL speaker unless you leave it with one of the persistent shopkeepers and trust that they would give it back to you afterwards . The Polish couple in front of us were just as disappointed that the notebook the girl had written in was not allowed inside . Why ? Its just one of the rules . When we left the Taj , the queues were even longer . Considering we queued for three times the time we spent inside , I was pleased we were first-in and first-out . Like the filthy sleeper train-ride back to Delhi in what felt like a jail cell with barred windows so dirty you could barely see out of them . Like the chaos , litter and rubbish you have to ignore when you make your way to a beautiful 5 - star resort for expensive ( by Indian standards ) sundowners . Perhaps India is not as geared to foreign tourism as South Africa is , perhaps repeat-visits are not encouraged , perhaps the Indian government have not thought about sustainable repeat tourism as an industry to build the economy on . Yes , a few friendly locals crossed our path with advice on what to do not to get ripped off and what the going rate of some things SHOULD be , At our hotel in Goa , Yogesh was the friendliest person we met on our Indian travels - even though we did not book excursions through him , he offered to take my phone to a repair shop and eagerly explained what the items on the repetitive breakfast menu were . What were the biggest negatives - 1 . RipoffsAlthough were savvy travellers and I have travelled extensively , we did not fall foul of the excessive scammers like our seedy taxi driver in Agra who first dropped us at a dodgy hotel then tried to convince us to use his expensive services for the whole day when he pulled to the side of the road in a sidestreet to show us a map and try an elaborate upsell . And the Tourism Office staff in a dodgy side street at Connaught Place in Delhi where they wanted us to cancel our pre-booked train tickets and spend double the time to get to the Taj at double the cost because the ride from Agra station to the monument would take a few hours anyway , when it actually took 20 minutes . But sometimes ripoffs are inevitable when you need a Tuk Tuk late at night and drivers refuse to haggle . You know you are being ripped off before the hotel concierge will laugh and agree at your misfortune , but you just want to get to bed . As a tourist , you must simply be prepared to pay more than locals for anything and everything , unless you go into a supermarket . Or have wifi to order Ubers . Uber is amazing and saved us lots of haggling and destination explanation . You do almost start feeling sorry for the scammers though , because when you see the desperation in traders to sell you something at an inflated price , you realise ( and are sometimes verbally reminded ) of priorities and their livelihood that are at stake . More of a reason to encourage repeat tourism rather than discourage current tourists ? On the beach in Goa , I eventually bought a bracelet for a friend from a tired-looking saleslady - probably exhausted from all the nos of being ignored by tourists on her stint up and down the long beach - and when we discussed having a G&T in her presence , she reminded me that a G&T will cost me three times what I paid for the bracelet and that I should rather give her the money . Reality-check - she probably has many mouths to feed back home and here I only bought one bracelet . Not exactly a ripoff for me , but I felt like Id cheated her out of money even though I supported her . In my run-in with the law in Goa , I was one of a few scooty drivers with a helmet , but still got stopped by the traffic cops ( along with other tourists ) as the locals sped by . Although my drivers licence was fine to hire the bike with , it was not good enough for the traffic officer . I had to then present an Indian-issued international drivers licence out of thin air . I refused to pay a Rs500 bribe so bravely offered to go to the police station with the traffic cop because my drivers licence would not transform into an Indian-issued international drivers licence even if I paid the bribe - and my current licence had been fine in Bali and Thailand too . He then released us . Although many of the potential ripoffs never happened or did not break the bank ( paying Rs1200 for a taxi vs Rs1500 was not going to bankrupt us they were tiring and unnecessary . And if we were not savvy or pushing back and questioning things , they could have cost us more . 2 . ChaosPicture driving on the N1 from Durbanville to Cape Town city centre or the M25 around London . Yes , the congestion is painful and slow especially at rush hour , but cars indicate when changing lanes , mostly keep left and pass right and patiently wait their turn . India is a free-for-all . As long as you can honk your horn , you can drive in the middle of the road and whizz in and out of lanes without checking your blindspot . I am amazed that we did not see more than three accidents . One of which we were involved in - when our taxi drove into the back of a Suzuki Swift throwing us all forward , but the Swift had a protecting metal bar which saved the bumper and we could all proceed after all the bystanders cleared us to proceed on our journey . The impact was hard and I expected a write-off ! You can turn your vehicle without looking for incoming traffic - as long as you hoot . You also have to honk your horn if you stay in your lane so that the vehicles in front of you do not just blindly move in front of you , or so that they know there is something behind them . By vehicles I mean cars , bicycles , taxis , tuktuks , horse-drawn carriages , pedestrians , dogs and the odd cow ( even in central Delhi ) . Perhaps back home were so used to the sound of a horn signalling an imminent accident or dangerous driving , that our stress levels automatically rise when we hear too many hooters . In my experience this holiday , unless you are at an airport , Indians rarely queue , so the night at 10pm when all machines except one ran out of travel tokens on the Metro in Delhi , we had to push to ensure wed eventually get to the front because panic started settling in as to if people would get travel tokens to get home . There was more pushing than at the Taj Mahal when the locals also incorrectly told us we were in the wrong queue . A good side to the chaos was a Delhi Food Tour which took us to dusty Old Delhi where we ate street food at street stalls we would normally have been too scared to eat at . Our guides navigated the streets and chaos for us to ensure we had a good chaotic day at various food stops . 3 . PollutionBlue skies seem a distant memory in India - even in Goa . Constant fires and smog add to the eternal haziness of Delhi and Goa . In the sea , the bathing water is sticky with plastic bags and weird objects floating by . The rust red sand which stains your shoes and nails is apparently from inland mining and construction . The seafood on display in the restaurants does not look appealing and the prawns and calamari I ate were tasteles . Apparently , the seafood quality has deteriorated due to heavily polluted waters and streams and contamination has resulted in todays Goa not having the general appeal of 20 years ago . Perhaps I am spoilt with the seafood we get in SA . Litter lies everywhere and the locals can often be seen dropping their water bottles and plastic wrappers wherever they walk . The beaches are far from being unspoilt with glass and plastic strewn everywhere . Locals do not even dare put their lips onto waterbottles when they drink - it seems that everyone is ultra-careful of getting more germs than necessary in a society where washing your hands with hot soapy water seems to become a luxury for the middle-class . What type of tourists seem to go to Goa - Perhaps a far cry from Goa of 20 years ago , the typical younger foreign tourist visiting Goa today seem to be hippy-types - many dreadlocked , heavily tattooed and multiple body-piercings visitors seemed the order of the day . Otherwise there seemed to be many pensioners ( mostly British or Russian ) who perhaps do not mind the litter and pollution in contrast to the value-for-money deals they could afford here . Or they have been visiting repeatedly , so might not have noticed the deteriorating surroundings over the years . Thick red dust , dirt and grime has not deterred them from coming back from a budget ( but tacky ) destination . Repeat travel - On Wednesday I arrive in Bali for my second visit to Indonesia and I do hope to visit Thailand for a third time next year . I do also still want to visit Vietnam and Cambodia . I came to India with an open mind and am happy to have visited . Perhaps I have high standards and expectations after too many years of travelling . But travelling can never be too much , it opens your eyes so much that you always want to experience more , even with disappointments along the way . Looking forward to the next chapter !

review_body: Our long awaited visit to the magnificent and beautiful Taj Mahal with an excellent and informative guide was truly ruined by seeing the condition of the starved , weak horses slipping and stumbling as they tried to pull the tourist laden Tonga carts on the totality unsuitable marble road surface leading to the front gate . We understand that in India most of the animals are slim and have work to do and we were generally impressed with how the animals were looked after in Rajasthan , however the condition of the horses and donkeys pulling these carts in Agra was very distressing and completely ruined our experience and memories of our visit to the Taj Mahal . Please DO NOT encourage this cruelty and inform your tour operator BEFORE you visit because if you just refuse the ride on the day , the guide and the horse owner will have already been paid . We were too distressed to take photographs of the terrible condition of these horses which we now regret as most also had sores from the harnesses and looked completely emaciated ! The short walk along the marble road is only a few minutes but if it is too far there are plenty of rickshaws which are far more suitable and ultimately will make for a more enjoyable overall experience .

Instead I found myself entering a group of infernal rows of Indian visitors ( Christmas period is holiday for them too ) by the thousands . Inside the monument , a Dante circle of forced rows among soldiers who continually whistle and scream , especially in the room where there are the tombs of Mumtaz and of her beloved husband . The site is in the hands of the military , I suppose for anti-terrorism reasons . On the river a fence with barbed wire should perhaps prevent terrorist attacks . Meanwhile , the charm of the most beautiful monument in the world has set forever .

review_body: All my life I have heard about the beauty and wonder of the Taj Mahal . Sadly my visit was quite a let down . First a tried the moon light visit , only 50 people at a time . Unfortunately it was a rainy night and you only get to look at the Taj from a distance like in the picture . There was no lighting so it was virtually impossible to see the Taj at all . That combined with the humidity and the overwhelming security made it feel like a waste of money and time . Figured it would be better in the day . So went back the next day . Security was lighter and the outside proportions and color of the Taj are attractive despite the obvious poor restoration attempts in some of the arches . The inside was not lit and access to the impressive peitra dura was blocked by the teaming crowds of tourists as well as security cameras . Access to the lower floor and the actual tombs with the finest artwork was completely walled off . Bottom line , in my humble opinion there are many far more inspiring and beautiful monuments elsewhere in India .

I never wrote a review for my first trip but decided it was necessary for this trip . If you are going with a large guided trip then this may not apply to you but as a small group driving your own car , read on . Firstly , get there as EARLY as possible , the crowd explodes around noon and it is not even pleasant near that time for walking inside the Taj Mahal itself . it is 100 rupees to park at the east or west car park , since the entire area is based on symmetry , they are exactly alike and just go to the one closest for you . You will instantaneously be picked up in the park by a team consisting of an electric bike with driver , and a tour guide . They will take you directly to the Taj Mahal entrance from your car if you so choose , for 100-150 rupees . While on the ride , the tour guide will offer you his services and show you his guide ID card with two different prices , one for Indian and one for foreigners 1,200 , and 2,275 rupees respectively . He will likely offer you the Indian price if you are hesitant , and pretty much force you into buying his services . If it is at peak hours , he really will get you through all of the lines quickly but his pitch about the lower price is a flat out lie and when it comes time to pay he will still charge foreigners price and expect a tip for the VIP package . Both times I went I had that exact scenario . The ticket for entry is 1,000 rupees for North Americans , Australians and Europeans , 550 for Asian and South Americans . Plus 10 rupees per person for shoe covers and a bottle of water . You will then proceed to the Royal Gate and have a little story time outside , then go up to the gate for photos , where you will be swarmed with that tour guides photographer friends to sell you their services , and I mean hounded , then upon entering the courtyard you will again be hounded by photographers every step of the way until about midway to Taj Mahal itself . Up to you if you want it , they give photos in a decent little album after your tour is done , also on CD or USB for varying prices starting near 2,000 rupees . Congratulations , you have made it through the hustlers , for now . But inside the Taj Mahal there will be a security guy on the other side of the fence , he will show you how the marble looks with a flashlight and shout your name so you can hear the echo , then he will expect a small tip for his services , we gave 10 rupees and he was okay with it . After finishing the inside tour , hearing the history and seeing the incredible craftsmanship , which is what you actually came for , including the guest house and mosque , the really negative things begin . The tour guide will immediately begin talking up the 17 generations of craftsmen , this is all to get you interested in their sales , which will be friends of his that he has colluded with to make sales . You will depart through a side gate into the workers colony , which is beyond sketchy ( keep you hand on your wallet and phone pockets at all times here ) . The ATM is conveniently located right out the gate and amid hundreds of people from ages 4 to 104 shouting at you to buy their cups or fridge magnets . This is the art of the tour I tried to avoid the second time but the tour guide will have nothing of the sort . He will take you to a shop where they will try to sell you many things made from marble and pretty stones , which are very nice but I paid 100 US dollars for a 2 inch elephant , after haggling . The prices are absolutely unbelievably high . After leaving the shops things get even more sketchy as the route is full of twists , turns and suspicious looking guys pretending to talk on phones while watching your every more , do not stop , do not talk , just go back to your car . After the exit you will arrive right back at the ticket area and will need to buy another ride back to the car park , and pay your guide . When you get back to the car park the hustlers will try everything in their power to get you to buy ANYTHING , all the way to the car , and at your window . Probably a good time to mention that if you parked in an actual parking space , by now you are very likely boxed in by a parallel parked car , which may or may not be in neutral for you to move it and depart . For us it was luckily the former . All in all the place is lovely . But , the hustlers and hagglers , and general pushiness of everyone to get you to buy extras made us extremely frustrated on both ends of the tour . Outside the Taj Mahal afterwards feels like you are swimming in chummed water during Shark Week , and completely ruins the experience .

On the whole , India has had more disappointing moments than good vibes , As a South African , when I see tourists or have guests , I try to personally help them have a good time . Thankfully , for tourists in sunny SA , that is usually easy to do . Tourists to SA pay the same for services , taxis and experiences as our locals and thankfully , rip-offs are rare . they are also made to feel welcome - you would want them to come back . I am grateful for my experiences and senses here in India nonetheless . Somewhat of a if you have not travelled to India , you have not REALLY travelled-scenario . Perhaps I have high standards and yes , this has been the cheapest holiday ever in terms of food and transport ( even with the numerous unwanted tourist rate hikes but cleanliness and pollution is a bigger negative to India . If I were at a different lifestage , pehaps Id feel different . India never made it onto my travel bucketlist until a good friends wedding invite for her wedding . Then we were told less than a month before our departure that she would not be coming to India after-all , so the reunion plans were also cancelled . We changed our internal flights ( at a fee ) from Amritsar to spend more time in Delhi and Goa , rather than losing more money by cancelling flights and accommodation or being stuck in rural India where the wedding would have been , for 10 days . From day one , the trip became a love / hate expedition . Five days in , until the 2nd day in Goa , it felt more like hard work than a holiday . The scams , haggling and different treatment of tourists - as cash cows - led to a repeated bitter taste compared to the fewer positives ( the food in Delhi was probably of the most flavoursome I have eaten ) . Safe to say that I will not be back in India in a hurry . Not even for a good curry . Even if the postponed wedding becomes a reality . What were the positives - The food and our 5 - star Delhi hotel for the first part of our trip being the two main highlights , there were a few moments like seeing the Taj Mahal and having sundowners with awesome friends on Goan shores that were great . But all the positives except the Taj can be found in other ( more relaxing and cleaner ) holiday destinations . Yes , our pictures are amazing ! We had some great sundowners and lovely sunsets . But often the behind-the-scenes work in creating those positive images were less glamorous . Like the chaos before entering the Taj Mahal with queues , ticket touts , persistent shopkeepers and signage saying that there are free lockers inside the monument , only to be told at the security scanners it is not true - that the guards will confiscate your snacks , books and JBL speaker unless you leave it with one of the persistent shopkeepers and trust that they would give it back to you afterwards . The Polish couple in front of us were just as disappointed that the notebook the girl had written in was not allowed inside . Why ? Its just one of the rules . When we left the Taj , the queues were even longer . Considering we queued for three times the time we spent inside , I was pleased we were first-in and first-out . Like the filthy sleeper train-ride back to Delhi in what felt like a jail cell with barred windows so dirty you could barely see out of them . Like the chaos , litter and rubbish you have to ignore when you make your way to a beautiful 5 - star resort for expensive ( by Indian standards ) sundowners . Perhaps India is not as geared to foreign tourism as South Africa is , perhaps repeat-visits are not encouraged , perhaps the Indian government have not thought about sustainable repeat tourism as an industry to build the economy on . Yes , a few friendly locals crossed our path with advice on what to do not to get ripped off and what the going rate of some things SHOULD be , At our hotel in Goa , Yogesh was the friendliest person we met on our Indian travels - even though we did not book excursions through him , he offered to take my phone to a repair shop and eagerly explained what the items on the repetitive breakfast menu were . What were the biggest negatives - 1 . RipoffsAlthough were savvy travellers and I have travelled extensively , we did not fall foul of the excessive scammers like our seedy taxi driver in Agra who first dropped us at a dodgy hotel then tried to convince us to use his expensive services for the whole day when he pulled to the side of the road in a sidestreet to show us a map and try an elaborate upsell . And the Tourism Office staff in a dodgy side street at Connaught Place in Delhi where they wanted us to cancel our pre-booked train tickets and spend double the time to get to the Taj at double the cost because the ride from Agra station to the monument would take a few hours anyway , when it actually took 20 minutes . But sometimes ripoffs are inevitable when you need a Tuk Tuk late at night and drivers refuse to haggle . You know you are being ripped off before the hotel concierge will laugh and agree at your misfortune , but you just want to get to bed . As a tourist , you must simply be prepared to pay more than locals for anything and everything , unless you go into a supermarket . Or have wifi to order Ubers . Uber is amazing and saved us lots of haggling and destination explanation . You do almost start feeling sorry for the scammers though , because when you see the desperation in traders to sell you something at an inflated price , you realise ( and are sometimes verbally reminded ) of priorities and their livelihood that are at stake . More of a reason to encourage repeat tourism rather than discourage current tourists ? On the beach in Goa , I eventually bought a bracelet for a friend from a tired-looking saleslady - probably exhausted from all the nos of being ignored by tourists on her stint up and down the long beach - and when we discussed having a G&T in her presence , she reminded me that a G&T will cost me three times what I paid for the bracelet and that I should rather give her the money . Reality-check - she probably has many mouths to feed back home and here I only bought one bracelet . Not exactly a ripoff for me , but I felt like Id cheated her out of money even though I supported her . In my run-in with the law in Goa , I was one of a few scooty drivers with a helmet , but still got stopped by the traffic cops ( along with other tourists ) as the locals sped by . Although my drivers licence was fine to hire the bike with , it was not good enough for the traffic officer . I had to then present an Indian-issued international drivers licence out of thin air . I refused to pay a Rs500 bribe so bravely offered to go to the police station with the traffic cop because my drivers licence would not transform into an Indian-issued international drivers licence even if I paid the bribe - and my current licence had been fine in Bali and Thailand too . He then released us . Although many of the potential ripoffs never happened or did not break the bank ( paying Rs1200 for a taxi vs Rs1500 was not going to bankrupt us they were tiring and unnecessary . And if we were not savvy or pushing back and questioning things , they could have cost us more . 2 . ChaosPicture driving on the N1 from Durbanville to Cape Town city centre or the M25 around London . Yes , the congestion is painful and slow especially at rush hour , but cars indicate when changing lanes , mostly keep left and pass right and patiently wait their turn . India is a free-for-all . As long as you can honk your horn , you can drive in the middle of the road and whizz in and out of lanes without checking your blindspot . I am amazed that we did not see more than three accidents . One of which we were involved in - when our taxi drove into the back of a Suzuki Swift throwing us all forward , but the Swift had a protecting metal bar which saved the bumper and we could all proceed after all the bystanders cleared us to proceed on our journey . The impact was hard and I expected a write-off ! You can turn your vehicle without looking for incoming traffic - as long as you hoot . You also have to honk your horn if you stay in your lane so that the vehicles in front of you do not just blindly move in front of you , or so that they know there is something behind them . By vehicles I mean cars , bicycles , taxis , tuktuks , horse-drawn carriages , pedestrians , dogs and the odd cow ( even in central Delhi ) . Perhaps back home were so used to the sound of a horn signalling an imminent accident or dangerous driving , that our stress levels automatically rise when we hear too many hooters . In my experience this holiday , unless you are at an airport , Indians rarely queue , so the night at 10pm when all machines except one ran out of travel tokens on the Metro in Delhi , we had to push to ensure wed eventually get to the front because panic started settling in as to if people would get travel tokens to get home . There was more pushing than at the Taj Mahal when the locals also incorrectly told us we were in the wrong queue . A good side to the chaos was a Delhi Food Tour which took us to dusty Old Delhi where we ate street food at street stalls we would normally have been too scared to eat at . Our guides navigated the streets and chaos for us to ensure we had a good chaotic day at various food stops . 3 . PollutionBlue skies seem a distant memory in India - even in Goa . Constant fires and smog add to the eternal haziness of Delhi and Goa . In the sea , the bathing water is sticky with plastic bags and weird objects floating by . The rust red sand which stains your shoes and nails is apparently from inland mining and construction . The seafood on display in the restaurants does not look appealing and the prawns and calamari I ate were tasteles . Apparently , the seafood quality has deteriorated due to heavily polluted waters and streams and contamination has resulted in todays Goa not having the general appeal of 20 years ago . Perhaps I am spoilt with the seafood we get in SA . Litter lies everywhere and the locals can often be seen dropping their water bottles and plastic wrappers wherever they walk . The beaches are far from being unspoilt with glass and plastic strewn everywhere . Locals do not even dare put their lips onto waterbottles when they drink - it seems that everyone is ultra-careful of getting more germs than necessary in a society where washing your hands with hot soapy water seems to become a luxury for the middle-class . What type of tourists seem to go to Goa - Perhaps a far cry from Goa of 20 years ago , the typical younger foreign tourist visiting Goa today seem to be hippy-types - many dreadlocked , heavily tattooed and multiple body-piercings visitors seemed the order of the day . Otherwise there seemed to be many pensioners ( mostly British or Russian ) who perhaps do not mind the litter and pollution in contrast to the value-for-money deals they could afford here . Or they have been visiting repeatedly , so might not have noticed the deteriorating surroundings over the years . Thick red dust , dirt and grime has not deterred them from coming back from a budget ( but tacky ) destination . Repeat travel - On Wednesday I arrive in Bali for my second visit to Indonesia and I do hope to visit Thailand for a third time next year . I do also still want to visit Vietnam and Cambodia . I came to India with an open mind and am happy to have visited . Perhaps I have high standards and expectations after too many years of travelling . But travelling can never be too much , it opens your eyes so much that you always want to experience more , even with disappointments along the way . Looking forward to the next chapter !

Not sure why this monument gets so much attention with so many beautiful sites in India . Frankly I was not as impressed as I thought I would be ! It was about 120 degrees out so there were not too many people there . Was saddened by the abject poverty surrounding the Taj . Even the horses used to transport visitors looked like they were going to drop dead at any second . Overall , for the amount of money that comes in through ticket sales , it is very discouraging to see the lack of infrastructure in Agra and around the Taj . It exists in so many other areas that do not have 1 / 10th of the visitors , so where does the income go ? But what was most upsetting is that visitors refuse to follow any rules ! You are not allowed to take photos but everyone was taking selfies , in a mausoleum ! You are not allowed to linger and families were eating on the floor . You have to wear shoe covers and the guards do not bother to ask you to throw them in the bins , there are thousands of them littering the entire grounds . Very sad .

Far from what we expected . We booked a sunrise visit and we could not see 6 inches in front of us with the fog ! No guarantees of weather here . We waited and waited for the fog to lift but to no avail . Our guide advised us to go as it would be too busy leaving it till the afternoon . He was not kidding - it was awful . Queues everywhere . Even though there is a Westerners Queue because we pay more it was still like a cattle market . Diana's bench - could not get near it . To top the lot we ended up paying a guy there with his camera for some photoshop photos he was selling . 30 for a small albumThe Taj itself was only allowing people to view in one section . Scaffolding around one side . Cars were not allowed anywhere near the Taj and we had to get out well before we got there to take an electric vehicle because of the pollution may damage the marble . The so called Special Marble was being washed in the dirtiest rags you have ever seen in the dirtiest water . I questioned the guide about this ! Also no photos were allowed inside - UNLESS YOU TIP THE GUARD THERE - lots of money being thrown at his feet ! WHAT A HUGE DISAPPOINTMENT - FARCE - wish we had not bothered .

Disappointing is the adjective that sums up the Taj Mahal experience . The architecture is great , the story interesting but that is where the romantic notion stops . The whole experience is marred by the people who just do not care about anything but money , from the government to the grounds staff , no one has any sense of pride in their work , the Taj Mahal or the guests who are lining their corrupt pockets . 1000 rupees per person to go in to visit the Taj Mahal , we visited at 0600 to see the sunrise via the East Gate . Our pre arranged taxi did not turn up , so we asked Security at our hotel ( Marriott Courtyard ) to call us a tuk tuk . Immediately we had a lift and for 300 rupees return , we were sorted cheaper than the taxi who wanted to charge double for the 3km return journey ) . After buying our ticket from the booking office ( approx 700m from the entrance collecting our included bottle of water and shoe covers ( which must be worn in the mausoleum ) and took a rickshaw to the entrance for 100 rupees each way . We did not try bartering with either of our two drivers as it was still cheaper than the taxi driver . Unfortunately , opportunists are everywhere trying to get you to buy their services for a photo , their rickshaw ( even though you have one a tour , a souvenir , clothes etc . Having to repeatedly say no thank you is exhausting and frustrating , especially when you are not being listened to but just harassed . Upon entry , you go through security , metal detectors and X-Ray for bags . Men on right , women on left side . More photographers and guides ( official / unofficial you cannot tell and apparently a lot of ID is fake not that I would know what I am looking at in the first place ) ! trying to get you to buy their services . The view is lovely with the garden and water fountains before you leading to the mausoleum . When you near the steps to the mausoleum , you have to put your shoe covers on ( or remove your shoes altogether ) . it is not the sun coming over the horizon that you see but the sun climbing up into the sky . As one should have realised , this gives a very slight yellow ( golden is a bit poetic license ) tinge to the marble , although the semi precious stones that are the flower art work do glint in the light . Inside the mausoleum it is dark and difficult to see the artwork clearly Pay close attention to the rules . Only take a camera , phone and water with you . More than likely you will be made to dispose of anything else ( or go back to the booking office to store in a locker that is limited and on a first come , first served basis ) . The lack of care is sad to see . There are shoe covers and water bottles disregarded all over the gardens ( the majority of national people seem to think littering is acceptable why these cannot be disposed of carefully or picked up by the grounds staff ( instead of them trying to point you to the best vantage point then asking for tips ) is just thoughtless and lazy . On the return , ( as previously mentioned ) you are harassed , however , the rickshaw and tuk tuk drivers we had were polite , courteous and reliable . The hype of the Taj Mahal exceeds the reality . We have visited Humayun's Tomb in Delhi and the mausoleums within Lodi Gardens that are also in Delhi that are equally beautiful if not quite as well renovated . Yesterday we took said taxi that let us down this morning to the other side of the Yamuna river for a view at sunset for 600 rupees return . 200 rupees each to get into Mehtab Burj ( ruins of a supposed planned black Taj Mahal for emperor Shah Jahan ) so that we could see the Taj Mahal as the sun set . It was ok but did not WOW us . My advice is to read up on the history before you go rather than hire a guide and save yourself 1000 rupees . Good luck !

My first negative review and sadly it had to be for this world famous wonder of the world . What a terrible letdown this was . The review is not for the monument itself . The architecture of the Taj is absolutely breathtaking but everything else around is just so very horrible . Our first view was in the evening from across the river ( with barely any water left ) on the other side . We wanted a nice sunset view but all we got in our photos was food trash , plastic bottles , plastic wrappers . The grass seems like it has not had a trim for decades . The walk towards the river to get the view is filled with the smell of human waste . The journey and walk towards either of the gates is barely any better . There is garbage strewn all around , there is a tout to harass you literally every step . This is not how you maintain a national treasure . The whole experience even before you see the Taj itself is so depressing and unpleasant . There are ten thousand better things to see and do in Incredible India . If I could rewind back the clock , I would skip Agra altogether , stay in Bharatpur and spend a whole day or two in Keoladeo National Park . It would have been time more well spent .

Inside the monument , a Dante circle of forced rows among soldiers who continually whistle and scream , especially in the room where there are the tombs of Mumtaz and of her beloved husband . The beauty of the Taj is unprecedented , it simply is a must see in your lifetime . My review of the Taj focuses more on how we were treated there . The entire experience was appalling and we were so angry with how we were treated , that it almost ruined our visit . We are a family of Indian descent but are 5th generation South African , that being said , I do not speak a word of Hindi . Trying to enter the Taj , there is 2 lines , a tourist line and a national line . The security personnel saw us in the tourist line ( which is significannotly shorter than the line for nationals ) and screamed for us to get to the back of the national line , based on her assumption that we were nationals . We explained that we were foreigners and we were in the correct line , after which we were mocked and met with laughter for the fact that we were Indian's speaking English . All backpacks have to go through a security check before entering the Taj . The security felt the need to allow every other foreign tourist through without checking their bags but just had to stop our family and critically check each of us . In my backpack , I had a sample of my wedding invitation . They found this and started shouting at me and demanded that I throw it in the trash . We could not understand why , they were literally just giving us a hard time for no reason . Our tour guide had to intervene to stop the security from their absolutely psychotic behaviour . The security personnel need to seriously re-evaluate their attitude and how they treat tourists , irrespective of what I look like or where I am from , I deserve to be treated with respect , especially if I am prepared to visit your country and bring in money to support tourism . I would have enjoyed the Taj far more had we actually been treated with dignity by the staff .

This was one of the least pleasant experiences of visiting sites around India . Everything seems geared towards people getting ripped off . Our plan had been to arrive at dawn , and I am sure we would have had a more positive experience if that was the case , but a late train meant we arrived in mid-morning . After deciding to go to the South Gate to make sure we could get through in time and beat the queues at West Gate , we discovered that , despite MASSIVE SIGNS and every form of guide and reference advertising it , there was NO CLOAK ROOM AT THE SOUTH GATE . So we had to get ripped off by local shop keepers to hold our bags for us , or waste our time walking over to the West Gate and standing in line for twice as long . Once we got the ticket , we once again encountered bureaucratic nonsense , a paper coffee cup and a cardboard sign we had written , to take sentimental photos as we were missing my mother in law's birthday back home , were confiscated at the gate . Why ? They did not read the sign and decide it was a bad message ( happy birthday ) ? We had about 45 minutes to get into the place by this point so there was no time to argue . In the bin . I am sure the soldiers at the gate were shaking us down for a bribe , we would not give them the satisfaction . Honestly , we expect touts and those who profit from tourism , but not this kind of treatment from the police or armed forces . What scum . Paper and cardboard are no risk to safety , we would have happily held onto them and brought them back out with us so we were not putting undue strain on the bins inside , bureaucratic nonsense . The numbers of tourists were immense by the time we got inside . Fair enough , it is a world wonder . But for all this money coming in , why is it being so poorly managed ? A bloody cloak room is not a hard thing to administer , it would have made everything about our visit easier and more enjoyable . it is a shame that the administrators of this amazing site think of foreign tourists as cash cows with no need for pleasant treatment .

I visited the Taj with a group of friends and our friend from Delhi . The Taj is something that was on each of our bucket lists , and I can say that it fell completely short of any expectations . Here's why - Getting There It is a brutal drive from Delhi because of city traffic . There is little to do in Agra , which is a very poor , dirty city located near the Taj When you arrive on grounds , tuk tuk and camel drivers will swarm you to have them take you from the parking lot to the entrance gate 200 meters ) . - You will also be solicited by street vendors and children trying to steal your bags or beg for money . MIND YOUR BELONGINGS . At the Taj You will take some beautiful photographs Photographs you could have seen in a magazine rather than endure + 100 degree temperatures and hoards of people for There are no restrooms All you can do is walk the grounds , walk inside the mausoleum , and walk into the mosques on either side of the main building . Let me emphasize - ALL you can do is WALK AROUND The buildings are beautiful , and the stories and legends behind it make it enchanting , but the actual visit itself is lackluster As a foreigner , we as both in a group and individually were approached by dozens of Indian families and for pictures . In the two hours we spent there , we hard our pictures taken by + 20 Indians / families . Other Details As a small aside , unlike other historic monuments , the Taj does not have anything to describe what you are seeing ( i.e. tours , brochures , plaques ) . There are literally only the grounds , and nothing else , so read up before you visit Bring water with you . There is nothing sold on the grounds , so you will regret not having something to drink with you before venturing out .

We expect some targeting of tourists when we visit locations such as the Taj Mahal , but nothing could prepare us for the aggressive nature of the harassment we received before the gates , at the gates and after entering the gates - even though we were traveling as a family . We even encountered individuals within the sacred space of the mosoleum asking us for money . As we attempted to get to the state transfer vehicles , six rickshaws rode in our pathway to block our access . I am afraid that after two full days of travel to see this monument , instead of memories of how beautiful it is - I am left still shaking from unsafe my family felt visiting there .

I do not know what it is with local Indians who for some reason think all foreigners have just crawled from under a stone , most of us are not backward at coming forward and when we have prebooked a car / driver to take us to Agra via the expressway do not need any pathetic attempts at being scammed for the already prepaid toll fees , we also do not need a bogus tour guide waiting for us to arrive at the hotel to then tell us that we will not be allowed into the Taj Mahal without a registered guide . The visitors entrance to the Taj Mahal is unkempt and tawdry , the streets are strewn with litter , hawkers and unsavoury characters . TheTaj complex itself is disappointing in that considering it as unesco status , no attempts have been made to repair the gardens let alone the actual monuments , the avenue of thuja's along the canal are in sad state , the fountains do not work properly if at all and the tank is full of algae , the mausoleum was dirty and overcrowded with locals flouting the no photography / do not touch signs while attendants / guards wearily waved them on . Best time to go is very early in the morning , wait outside until it opens . review_body: I really do not understand why this building is so famous . it is pretty , but really nothing spectacular compared to , for example , the Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque in Istanbul , or almost any Roman ruins or major cathedrals in Europe . I expected a lot more from a world site this well-known , and was very disappointed . It felt like a waste of a lot of time and money to get over to there . The preservation really needs some serious work . Also , they need to education visitors about the importance of respecting and not damaging important historic sites . People have chipped away at sections of marble , which was sad to see . There are cracks that needs repairing , and the whole thing did not look like they kept it clean enough . The grounds need some work also . The shrubs looked like someone hacked away at them with an electric saw and the grass is patchy and brown in some spots . For a world site and a place earning so much by charging each foreigner 5x the daily salary of many locals , you would think they could keep things in better shape .

ok , so before we went to india , i read some people's negative reviews of the taj and i thought , how is that possible ? but i was overwhelmed and frustrated by our visit . we booked a daytrip from jaipur to see the taj , which included a driver and a guide and stops at a few other places . we arrived around 10am , and the crush of people outside was overwhelming and chaotic , even by indian standards . so many touts and hawkers , and our guide kind of let them attack us , which was not fun . the foreign ticket includes a bottle of water and shoe covers , and the list of what you can bring in is restrictive , so be careful - pack light or leave bags in the car if possible . you will be patted down and walk through a metal detector , and bags will be screened . after getting through the crowd , dealing with hawkers , getting through security , and whatnot , we were already pretty exhausted . then it starts with all the cameramen touts and the tourists - and we were told it was not that busy at the time so i cannot imagine if we had been there at a busy time . our guide was trying to explain how beautiful the building is and that it was built for love , but i just was not buying it - why build it here when she died so far away and already had a tomb ? it seemed to be more about a show of power and wealth , and when i thought of all the chaos , poverty , and desperation outside , and how protected and worshipped this stupid building was , i started to hate being there and just could not see it as beautiful anymore , but as a symbol of everything that was wrong with india - pouring money and jewels into a building while people starve outside . also , whatever else it stands for , it is still a tomb , and the circus-like , consumer-driven atmosphere surrounding it felt wrong . also , our guide kind of took over our camera so we could have the same photos that every other tourist wants i guess - the taj framed in the arch of the entranceway , pretending to hold the top of the tomb - which felt tacky and also limited our personal engagement with experiencing the taj . maybe my line of thinking is unfair - the taj was built a looong time ago , and by people who are no longer in power in india , so maybe its all a moot point , and by paying to see it , im helping those impoverished people . and maybe the guide thought he was being helpful instead of disruptive . i do not know . but i really had a hard time enjoying it or feeling anything positive . it is very small inside the tomb , and the air is rather still , and there are signs to be quiet - but no one is and you are sort of pushed past the replica graves like cattle . it felt claustrophobic and disrespectful . throughout the tour , our guide kept pushing us to go see a marble workshop and learn how they make things like the taj , which was a come on to buy something from a shop he would get a kickback from . i am happy to support local artisans if i want to purchase something , but i did not , so , uncomfortable . the one part i did enjoy was standing on the back of the taj , facing the yamuna river . the river seemed to stretch on forever , and there was a refreshing breeze after the stale air of the inner tomb . also , i had made it through the taj , and it was kind of a relief to know we would be leaving soon . im not going to tell you not to go . maybe im too much of a pessimist to enjoy nice things or was just having a bad day . but i really did not enjoy my visit . i hope you fare better if you decide to go and that this helps you if you are unsure if you want to go .

Okay , I am not saying the Taj Mahal was terrible . It is always a wonderful opportunity to visit a place you have heard about all of your life . But as a Trip Advisor reviewer , I am warning you not to go inside . The outside is lovely . Inside is like a fun house that is not fun . Small , dark , crowded with nothing to see . If you doubt me , just ask the people at the exit if you should go in . My wife is a bit claustrophobic and I had to comfort her for the circular walk around the dark interior with people crowded cheek to jowl . There is no turning back . Enjoy the grounds and exterior but do not go through the tiny interior . You may also wish to avoid the sunrise visit , which will have you standing in line , in the dark before the gates open , just to wait for the rising sun to strike the Taj . All of that would have been fine except for having to depart for the bus 10 minutes before the morning sunlight ever touched the building . As a photographer , I was really griped that the shot I waited for , crouching in the perfect position to get , was missed by such a short period of time . The sunset photos were better . Skip sunrise unless you have control over the departure time .

Again to my surprise the vehicle was only to cover half the distance only . I continued walking towards the monument for another kilometer and found myself in the queue as long as Great Wall of China . Sad sad sad , to top it up was the rude behavior of the security force at the monument . They do not care if its women , children or elderly people , they have only learnt the language of PUSH . The only saving grace was the magnificent white marble monument shining in the bright sun . But it looked no different in the pictures and videos available in the books and online . Here comes the worse of all , the security gaurd at the entrance of the tomb started to push hundreds of people physically into the center hall and then pushed out without even getting an opportunity to take a glimpse of the toms of Shah Jahan and Mumtaz Mahal . that is it this washed all my love for this monument and I left the city of Agra with great disappointment and just getting out of the traumatic experience . As for the Taj Mahal itself , its not flood lit so even in a full moon you can hardly see it . You can only enter just through the gateway on a platform so you are a long way away from the actual monument . Make sure you plan your moon light visit , otherwise , like us , the moon will be the opposite side of the sky to the Taj so will not even get into the picture ( that is if you have learned how to operate your camera's manual settings otherwise you will just get a blank screen ) .

Unpleasant experience due to masses of people ( all trying to cram into the inside of the Taj / take selfies at every opportunity ) . Would only go extremely early in the morning to avoid the crowds ( we could not do this as there was severe smog when we were in Agra ) . do not feel bad if you skip it - it is nicer on Google images !

On my last day in India my girlfriend and I decide to hire a car and go all the way to Agra from Delhi . From the moment we landed in the country to that point there ha been nothing but praise for the Taj Mahal . Well to make a long story short it was not worth the 5 + hour car trip , tickets to get in or the guide we for some reason were required to have . Please do not waste any time seeing this the greatest letdowns ever .

Yes the Taj is lovely but the experience was horrible . After paying a gazillion times more as a foreigner to support the upkeep of the Taj , I stand in line for almost two hours with everyone else , including obviously well off Indian tourists . The men's line was moving 3 times faster as they had more metal detectors and screeners . I am a patient person but the conditions were deplorable . It was so bad there was an actual riot by the end of the line . All the women were yelling and shoving past security . The security was overwhelmed with the reactions as everyone just started busting through . Keep hundreds of woman in cattle like conditions in the heat for a few hours , what did they expect ? We just could not breath anymore ! After finally making it through I had a few breaths of space and air , only to be set upon by a constant barrage of harassment from touts that surrounded me and blocked my way . Bottom line - India if you expect tourists to pay a ridiculous amount more to support the upkeep of your sites , start treating them with some respect , call off the harassers and treat women equally ! Perhaps instead of selling Indian vs Foreigner tickets , you could sell general admission vs VIP tickets as they do in most countries . That way you give all nationalities ( including tourists who are Indian nationals ) the opportunity to choose / pay for special treatment ( such as shorter lines ) or join the general stream . Bottom line - I would have paid double the admission to have avoided this terrible experience altogether .
