review_body: I am convinced that this is one of the most beautiful buildings in the world , but Agra does it is best to ruin whatever atmosphere of love and harmony Taj Mahal musters up . All though I am not so sure about the love part in the first place , having learned the familiy story about the empereror that built it . I guess architecture alone just does not do it for me . This was just another been there , done that - experience I could have been without . Since we went several hours by car to do Taj , we wanted to do the most out of it and hired a guide . He showed a certificate , had fixed price and was well worth the money .
Gone first time with friends its not that white like it was earlier repair work is gone on i do not like it like a wonder of the world it was just ok architecture its my personal view .

Taj Mahal , the name itself so heavy , I was expecting it to be the cleanest and most well-maintained monuments of all that I had seen , but to my dismay - The Taj Mahal has one of the most dirtiest and unclean entrances ever . There are many entry points but no boards which lead you to the right place . If UP Tourism is using Taj's name , why not make it better , My experience was pathetic . I had expected Taj to be flawless .

One of the worst experiences we have had in India thus far . We booked Agra bus tickets through a travel agent . The ticket price was 600 RS per person , 1200 in total for up and down . The ticket said it would pick us up from the place near to our New Delhi hotel at 6:15 am . But the bus came around 8ish . Though our tickets was for New Delhi - Agra - New Delhi , the travel agent did not tell us that it would take us to Mathura and Brindabon ( Two pilgrimage sites of Hindus ) . We were so shocked to find out about this ! We could not even see the Taj and Agra fort properly as the bus people only gave an hour to visit ( as they had to run off to those holy places ) . Being a foreigner who has no interest in Hinduism , I along with my family had to visit scary alleys of Mathura and Brindabon at 1AM in the night . What was supposed to be a simple bus ride to see Tajmahal , ended up being a 24 hours of nightmare . I was not the only sufferer , I saw many other foreign tourists who were going through the same nightmare . Tourists need to be aware of such touts while travelling that is why I thought it was necessary to review Taj . So pointers if you want to visit Taj - 1 ) do not go by bus or a travel agent . Bus company have contract with shops for food and souvenirs . They will spend hours in these shops rather than showing you the actual Taj . Best solution - Hire a taxi . it would be expensive , around 6 to 7 thousand rupees but will be worth every penny . 2 ) do not visit on Sunday . it is crowded . 3 ) Security is excessively tight . you are going to have to pay for your handy camera .
Very busy , over-rated and mainly hype . do not bother unless you are really into architecture . Completely forgettable apart from wondering what the big deal was .

do not do it . do not even think of going at night unless there is a moon high in the sky at visiting hours . This may be the only negative review for the Taj Mahal . it is everything out of your dreams in the daytime , but it is a serious disappointment at night . It takes 24 hours to book the visit with some ministry you have to take a cab to , you pay ( or you pay some tour guide to do it for you in advance ( they need passport copies you wait , you arrive for the visit and they strip you of everything except your camera , no kidding , not even water bottles are allowed , then they bus you to the entrance , you walk to the outer building and that is where you stand blocked by gates and guards to view way off in the sea of darkness , nothing , nothing . The mosquitoes know you are stuck there for 30 minutes , the same ones you saw hatching in those pretty reflecting ponds earlier are now taking full advantage of your helpless predicament . NO FLOODLIGHTS NO TAJ POOF DISAPPEARED NO PHOTOS , just skip it .

No one we booked with bothered to tell as the Taj is closed Friday's so when we arrived late Thursday night due to leave on the train Saturday 6am we had to rearrange our plan and booked a taxi for Saturday afternoon . On Saturday morning the Taj was closed again - and again no one informed us ! This time got a presidential visit . We returned when it opened at 12:15 and queued forever and then were released into ridiculous crowds making viewing difficult , unpleasant , stressful and unsatisfying . Yes it is beautiful but not worth seeing in this kind of crowd .

Taj Mahal standing proudly on the bank of the river Yamuna in Agra , is India's noble tribute to the grace of Indian womanhood . Built by Shahjehan , the 5th emperor of Mughal empire in the memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal , Taj Mahal is the largest and the most expensive mausoleum built by any man on earth The symbol of eternal love How I can go visit Taj Mahal .

I will not say that the Taj Mahal is not beautiful , it is certainly something to see in India . When you think of India , you think the Taj Mahal . However , it was not the most beautiful thing I found in India . There is so much hype going in to see the Taj Mahal , and what you find is a little dim in comparison to what you had expected . I had seen the Taj after traveling over much of India and besides the Taj I think there are ancient temples and forts that are far more extraordinary than the Taj Mahal . In my opinion the Golden Temple in Amritsar or the Amber Fort in Jaipur . Getting to the Taj Mahal is also frightening . Even compared to much of India , Agra is one of the most dirty and frightening places to travel to . The Taj Mahal is literally a gem sticking out of the middle of a coal mine . Inside the Taj it is beautifully kept , the water and the gardens are well maintained . It is very crowded inside , however . it is nearly impossible to get a picture with just you in it . Going anywhere outside of your hotel and the Taj Mahal is frightening . My friends and I went to find somewhere decent to eat in the vicinity of the Taj , and the best we found a a place on top of a roof and were served flourescent pasta along with some cockroaches . Bugs in the drinks even , not in the food . I am not sure how they managed that . I am not saying the Taj Mahal is not worth seeing , because I think it is one of those things where if you go to India it is a must-see . But , I would not suggest staying overnight there . There is not too much else to see that you cannot find in other states .

When I first saw the Taj Mahal 10 years ago , my breath was taken away . It was so beautiful , magnificent - and really captured India's history . Now , however , I feel as though India is somewhat ashamed of that history . As I understand it , an oil refinery has been set up not too many miles away . The atmosphere must therefore contain chemicals which can damage the beauty of the Taj Mahal . A structure that has lasted for centuries because of its amazing crafting is now slowly turning brown . I know what I saw , it did not have the same unique colour to it when I visited last month - there were bits of brown all over , and it did not have that spectacular glow . Emperor Shah Jahan made the Taj Mahal especially to enclose his wife's tomb , which is special within itself . But it is now losing its characteristic qualities , and within 100 years may be forgotten whilst India tries to promote other jewels within its land . I find it heartbreaking .

I have seen green grass before , a temple in marble standing around in the only clean place this country can offer , the only half an hour that I have not been harassed , chased , looked , a target for more money , honked and so on , Worth 20 dollars just to get way of the craziness of India . That marble thingy is just another construction more . I wish this country has more common sense than temples . A shame for the human kind .

My mother had not seen the Taj Mahal for fifty years and she asked us to tke her there . The politicians in Agra are reputed to be amongst the most corrupt in India and despite receiving a great deal of money in tourism revenues , no money has been spent in improving the infrastructure of that city . We hired a car for half a day but were given a run around by the driver and the guide who took us around to all kinds of expensive stores / restaurants rather than the sights we wanted to see . Getting into the Taj is a problem as there were queues at the main gate stretching back for two hours . There is another gate and one of the local guides presuaded us to part with a day's salary and take us to this entrance . No mobile phones are allowed inside and have to be left in the office . We were searched as is normal but the female guard took a fancy to a little plastic monkey charm that was attached to my Kipling rucksack . I knew I would never see it again and I put it in the office . The office closed at 5:00 pm and that meant I would not see the Taj at sunset , as we had planned to do . The monument is very busy inside and you need to watch your purse carefully . The grounds have been landscaped since my visit ten years ago and are quite pleasant to sit in and take a break from the heat , dust and the beggars and touts outside . Our taxi had left by now and we went back to the welcome comfort of our hotel , Clarks Shiraz . Would I come back to Agra ? No way !
would not go there another time . It looks nice , it is history is great but it misses the wow-factor . .

The surroundings of this wonder of the world is really bad , you have to dribble yourself through troublesome guides , horsecart people , auto rickshaws and so much dust and dirt , that when you reach inside to view the actual Taj mahal , the awe is just not enough . Had a very bad experience .

Obviously a fantastic building . No question about that at all . However , what a let down ! We were encouraged to see it early in the morning light but I suspect this was to ensure more visitors got in . Certainly there was no advantage as far as the quality of light was concerned . The problem lies in the pollution which Agra suffers from . The result is that you view this iconic building through a haze of smog - scarcely the romantic image you have taken from so many earlier photographs . In addition , comments regarding the poverty apparent to the rear of the Taj Mahal proved less accurate - my angst was more to do with the rubbish and other detritus that had been allowed to accumulate . All this might have been excusable when India was impoverished , but as a proud , independent , democratic - and relatively well off country - it should get its act together and sort these problems out ! Not , incidentally , by simply forcing local residents to move .

What you do not know on arrival in carpark , as part of the Rps1000 ticket you get a trip to and from the carpark in a motorised taxi . We hot harrased but supposefly official guides , then various horse and bicycle taxi drivers . Finally getting to the entrans we get an real guide for the Taj . The harrsment did not stop , we finally got upset and walked back to the carpark in heat and 100 % humidity . Been there , done that , never again . Our worst experience in India .

We are a family of five , with only one child under 15 and so it would have cost us 4000 rupees ( 60 euro ) to visit the Taj Mahal , compared to 40 rps for an Indian . As a result , there was a snaking queue of national tourists , and not a soul at the foreigners ticket office . We came across this tourist rate issue so many times in India , that time and again we found ourselves deciding it was just too much to pay . At other sites , the student rate for foreign tourists was denied to our children ( all under 18 ) because we did not have an official card to prove that they were still at school ( obligatory at their ages in our country ) . Highly frustrating . One reason we went to India was to enjoy a relatively cheap trip . We are not a rich family , even compared to some Indians , and found this foreign ticket policy left us with a frustrated , bitter taste that tainted our view of India .

I have expected so much more from all the history I read and pictures I had seen . What was the disappointment when you arrive and you see that it is actually less appealing than expected . Also it is rather hard to get to it as the cars are not allowed next to it , and need to leave a car far away and wait for the free shuttle which is not always available and crowded . The security at the entrance is very strict and does not allow bags , cigarettes , matches , or anything else , but camera or phone only . Do not forget to pick up complimentary water and covers for the shoes which are mandatory when you get on the marble . Inside is terribly hot , humid , dark and noisy . There are signs to keep it low , but the staff who works there blow the whistles hard to push the people move . Overall , can be visited to tick the box in your bucket list , but get prepared for some disappointment too .
The place is just ok . It smells terrible and is not organized . The city is horrible and apart from Taj , there is nothing to be visited .

I and my husband suffered a lot to enter . I did not liked the beggars outside the Taj . Maintainence is very poor . The Yamuna river behind the Taj was too very dirty . Nothing too exciting inside the tomb . Just the architecture with a grave . But one thing nice is that you can click some pics to show off . Overall , Taj Mahal has nothing special to be in the list of wonders of world .

avoid visiting in afternoon . & summer people there just making money from visitors the camera man , riksha wale , guide everyone is lying to tourists & making money & local govt . has no idea what is happening not at all good arrangement for the tourist as they are aware its being summer holiday lakhs of people visiting the TAJ Mahal but there no water available to drink only one water station where you will have thousand people in Que .

Not sure why this monument gets so much attention with so many beautiful sites in India . Frankly I was not as impressed as I thought I would be ! It was about 120 degrees out so there were not too many people there . Was saddened by the abject poverty surrounding the Taj . Even the horses used to transport visitors looked like they were going to drop dead at any second . Overall , for the amount of money that comes in through ticket sales , it is very discouraging to see the lack of infrastructure in Agra and around the Taj . It exists in so many other areas that do not have 1 / 10th of the visitors , so where does the income go ? But what was most upsetting is that visitors refuse to follow any rules ! You are not allowed to take photos but everyone was taking selfies , in a mausoleum ! You are not allowed to linger and families were eating on the floor . You have to wear shoe covers and the guards do not bother to ask you to throw them in the bins , there are thousands of them littering the entire grounds . Very sad .
It use to be a great place but its just another monument now . The long lines , people are always trying to con clients etc etc . Akshardham in Noida is much better than taj mahal .

Disappointing is the adjective that sums up the Taj Mahal experience . The architecture is great , the story interesting but that is where the romantic notion stops . The whole experience is marred by the people who just do not care about anything but money , from the government to the grounds staff , no one has any sense of pride in their work , the Taj Mahal or the guests who are lining their corrupt pockets . 1000 rupees per person to go in to visit the Taj Mahal , we visited at 0600 to see the sunrise via the East Gate . Our pre arranged taxi did not turn up , so we asked Security at our hotel ( Marriott Courtyard ) to call us a tuk tuk . Immediately we had a lift and for 300 rupees return , we were sorted cheaper than the taxi who wanted to charge double for the 3km return journey ) . After buying our ticket from the booking office ( approx 700m from the entrance collecting our included bottle of water and shoe covers ( which must be worn in the mausoleum ) and took a rickshaw to the entrance for 100 rupees each way . We did not try bartering with either of our two drivers as it was still cheaper than the taxi driver . Unfortunately , opportunists are everywhere trying to get you to buy their services for a photo , their rickshaw ( even though you have one a tour , a souvenir , clothes etc . Having to repeatedly say no thank you is exhausting and frustrating , especially when you are not being listened to but just harassed . Upon entry , you go through security , metal detectors and X-Ray for bags . Men on right , women on left side . More photographers and guides ( official / unofficial you cannot tell and apparently a lot of ID is fake not that I would know what I am looking at in the first place ) ! trying to get you to buy their services . The view is lovely with the garden and water fountains before you leading to the mausoleum . When you near the steps to the mausoleum , you have to put your shoe covers on ( or remove your shoes altogether ) . it is not the sun coming over the horizon that you see but the sun climbing up into the sky . As one should have realised , this gives a very slight yellow ( golden is a bit poetic license ) tinge to the marble , although the semi precious stones that are the flower art work do glint in the light . Inside the mausoleum it is dark and difficult to see the artwork clearly Pay close attention to the rules . Only take a camera , phone and water with you . More than likely you will be made to dispose of anything else ( or go back to the booking office to store in a locker that is limited and on a first come , first served basis ) . The lack of care is sad to see . There are shoe covers and water bottles disregarded all over the gardens ( the majority of national people seem to think littering is acceptable why these cannot be disposed of carefully or picked up by the grounds staff ( instead of them trying to point you to the best vantage point then asking for tips ) is just thoughtless and lazy . On the return , ( as previously mentioned ) you are harassed , however , the rickshaw and tuk tuk drivers we had were polite , courteous and reliable . The hype of the Taj Mahal exceeds the reality . We have visited Humayun's Tomb in Delhi and the mausoleums within Lodi Gardens that are also in Delhi that are equally beautiful if not quite as well renovated . Yesterday we took said taxi that let us down this morning to the other side of the Yamuna river for a view at sunset for 600 rupees return . 200 rupees each to get into Mehtab Burj ( ruins of a supposed planned black Taj Mahal for emperor Shah Jahan ) so that we could see the Taj Mahal as the sun set . It was ok but did not WOW us . My advice is to read up on the history before you go rather than hire a guide and save yourself 1000 rupees . Good luck !

The politicians in Agra are reputed to be among the most corrupt in India and despite receiving a great deal of money in tourism revenues , no money has been spent in improving the infrastructure of that city . Getting into the Taj is a problem as there were queues at the main gate stretching back for two hours . There is another gate and one of the local guides presuaded us to part with a day's salary and take us to this entrance . No mobile phones are allowed inside and have to be left in the office . The monument is very busy inside and you need to watch your purse carefully . The grounds have been landscaped and are quite pleasant to sit in and take a break from the heat , dust and the beggars and touts outside . The Taj Mahal is really suffering from age , neglect and pollution . The standard photos in books and post cards are very old and deceiving . I do not think it was worth it and I would recommend staying elsewhere and going over to see the Taj as an afternoon excursion . Better yet , take the one day return trip from New Delhi and do not stay in Agra at all . The color of the Taj is not good , it is chipped up and crumbling , and everyone seems to be in denial about how the neglect is effecting the beauty of this architectural wonder . I was shocked and very disappointed and saddened .

review_body: I regret to write this for our very own wonder which looks more like a disaster now . Soon this place would need disaster management on place of ASI . Battery vehicles could be seen parked in the garden and not operating coz its sunny for them to drive . ZERO management control , touts seems to dominate the area for everything leaving travellers to their mercy .

It goes without saying that is it is one of the wonders of the world , it is as magnificent as it is beautiful and everyone should see it while they can . This review is based on everything outside the gates , As Indians , but foreigners even we did not expect the kind of onslaught on bizarre men hounding us to pay them to be our tour guides / photographers / ricksaw drivers from the parking lot to gate ( about 500 meters ) . It started on the drive up to the west gate ( the best gate to get in from ) , Literally chasing our car until we parked , Barely letting us out of the car , and then proceeding to follow us the rest of the way . Wherever one would stop , 2-3 would begin . It was overwhelming , annoying and disgusting , In many ways it takes away from the actual beautify the moseleum is . As foreigners , here's the basic you need to know , 1 . Security is tight to enter , But anyone can enter with a ticket so be careful of pickpockets2 . no backpacks or day packs allowed , Women's purses are , but will be X-rayed3 . No food of any kind whatsoever is allowed and only water is permitted past security4 . Posted rate for non India residents was 1000 rupees , It comes with cold water , and shoe covers5 . If you take a tour guide , you bypass all line ups . We ended up taking a tour guide after purchasing the ticket , He acted as our photographer with OUR camera , not his own . Perhaps this was written prior , Figured I would write a review because clearly we were not expecting that . Being the tourist Mecca that it is , you would think it would be better and safer experience for people .
I waited more . Very expensive , nothing interesting . Agra fort is more exciting and chipper . There are a lot of visitors .

From a restaurant terrace we got amazing views of Taj Mahal , and we make awesome pictures . To go the inside the Taj was too expensive for foreign people , and we did not feel nothing special visiting this moschee . Before we visited other moschees in other country and the feelings were amazing .

From the time you enter there is local Indians waiting to rip you off , everyone seems to want to swindle a tourist . The camels that give you a ride are treated badly and are absolutely dirty their ridders also give you high prices at first but I recommend you bargain or just rather walk because the Tuk Tuk also want to rip you off . Then the locals selling stuff just want to rip you off , then you encounter various camera mens that want to rip you off and then the best is the so called tour guides also another bunch of corrupted individuals that want to make a quick buck of you , they do not even know the facts behind this monument . Then the busyness is unbarerable . As a tourist I paid 750 ruppees per a ticket to enter and locals pay 20 ruppees to enter , what a rip from the Indian Government . I would recommend you rather visit another tourist attraction .

People every where , crazy queues , bawling babies , old men & women . it was chaos , but the ancient Indian rope trick works money give it to the agents and you can get tickets and easy entry . Unless you are on an overpriced tour with an overfriendly Indian scam artist , you might have taken a train to Agra cannot station to get to the Taj Mahal . There will be a tuktuk booth outside and let me tell you upfront that the sellers are PACK ANIMALS . review_body: I went to Taj Mahal on January 26 with my family . I booked a zoom car . I reached there at 3.00 PM . Then when I want to park in the parking area they said no space available but there was . Then they said if we take their private parking area and guide it will cost 500 . We agreed to that since we had no option . Then we parked our car near the south gate near a cinema hall . Then we stood in the line for 45 min to enter the Tajmahal from the south gate . ( Very slow security checking . Like that of British era ) . Remember that the south gate closes by 5 PM , while the other gates ( East and West ) remain open till the sunset . You must carry ID cards to enter the Tajmahal . Sometimes they are rigid if you do not have . To enter the main building again you have to stay in line and you have to put cover on your shoes . The beauty of the Taj is unprecedented , it simply is a must see in your lifetime . My review of the Taj focuses more on how we were treated there . The entire experience was appalling and we were so angry with how we were treated , that it almost ruined our visit . We are a family of Indian descent but are 5th generation South African , that being said , I do not speak a word of Hindi . Trying to enter the Taj , there is 2 lines , a tourist line and a national line . The security personnel saw us in the tourist line ( which is significannotly shorter than the line for nationals ) and screamed for us to get to the back of the national line , based on her assumption that we were nationals . We explained that we were foreigners and we were in the correct line , after which we were mocked and met with laughter for the fact that we were Indian's speaking English . All backpacks have to go through a security check before entering the Taj . The security felt the need to allow every other foreign tourist through without checking their bags but just had to stop our family and critically check each of us . In my backpack , I had a sample of my wedding invitation . They found this and started shouting at me and demanded that I throw it in the trash . We could not understand why , they were literally just giving us a hard time for no reason . Our tour guide had to intervene to stop the security from their absolutely psychotic behaviour . The security personnel need to seriously re-evaluate their attitude and how they treat tourists , irrespective of what I look like or where I am from , I deserve to be treated with respect , especially if I am prepared to visit your country and bring in money to support tourism . I would have enjoyed the Taj far more had we actually been treated with dignity by the staff .

This was one of the least pleasant experiences of visiting sites around India . Everything seems geared towards people getting ripped off . Our plan had been to arrive at dawn , and I am sure we would have had a more positive experience if that was the case , but a late train meant we arrived in mid-morning . After deciding to go to the South Gate to make sure we could get through in time and beat the queues at West Gate , we discovered that , despite MASSIVE SIGNS and every form of guide and reference advertising it , there was NO CLOAK ROOM AT THE SOUTH GATE . So we had to get ripped off by local shop keepers to hold our bags for us , or waste our time walking over to the West Gate and standing in line for twice as long . Once we got the ticket , we once again encountered bureaucratic nonsense , a paper coffee cup and a cardboard sign we had written , to take sentimental photos as we were missing my mother in law's birthday back home , were confiscated at the gate . Why ? They did not read the sign and decide it was a bad message ( happy birthday ) ? We had about 45 minutes to get into the place by this point so there was no time to argue . In the bin . I am sure the soldiers at the gate were shaking us down for a bribe , we would not give them the satisfaction . Honestly , we expect touts and those who profit from tourism , but not this kind of treatment from the police or armed forces . What scum . Paper and cardboard are no risk to safety , we would have happily held onto them and brought them back out with us so we were not putting undue strain on the bins inside , bureaucratic nonsense . The numbers of tourists were immense by the time we got inside . Fair enough , it is a world wonder . But for all this money coming in , why is it being so poorly managed ? A bloody cloak room is not a hard thing to administer , it would have made everything about our visit easier and more enjoyable . it is a shame that the administrators of this amazing site think of foreign tourists as cash cows with no need for pleasant treatment .

I visited the Taj with a group of friends and our friend from Delhi . The Taj is something that was on each of our bucket lists , and I can say that it fell completely short of any expectations . Here's why - Getting There It is a brutal drive from Delhi because of city traffic . There is little to do in Agra , which is a very poor , dirty city located near the Taj When you arrive on grounds , tuk tuk and camel drivers will swarm you to have them take you from the parking lot to the entrance gate 200 meters ) . - You will also be solicited by street vendors and children trying to steal your bags or beg for money . MIND YOUR BELONGINGS . At the Taj You will take some beautiful photographs Photographs you could have seen in a magazine rather than endure + 100 degree temperatures and hoards of people for There are no restrooms All you can do is walk the grounds , walk inside the mausoleum , and walk into the mosques on either side of the main building . Let me emphasize - ALL you can do is WALK AROUND The buildings are beautiful , and the stories and legends behind it make it enchanting , but the actual visit itself is lackluster As a foreigner , we as both in a group and individually were approached by dozens of Indian families and for pictures . In the two hours we spent there , we hard our pictures taken by + 20 Indians / families . Other Details As a small aside , unlike other historic monuments , the Taj does not have anything to describe what you are seeing ( i.e. tours , brochures , plaques ) . There are literally only the grounds , and nothing else , so read up before you visit Bring water with you . There is nothing sold on the grounds , so you will regret not having something to drink with you before venturing out .

I am writing this in the exceptionally slim chance that some of the incompetent , inept and lazy Indian bureaucrats read this and change the visitor experience for foreigners . Ok , so the ticket price is a million times more for foreigners than it is for Indians , after cycling around India for three months I have just about become used to this racist , exploitative practice ( despite there being many millions of Indians who are more wealthy than me ) . 750 rupees compared to 20 . A large part of this is for the Agra Development Tax , presumably this is syphoned off as Agra is a smelly dump , the approach to the Taj is a complete mess and it acts as a gauntlet for scam artists and hustlers . You have to buy your ticket 1km away and start your journey to the architectural wonder by fending off pestering people who constantly hassle you . Sure this is common in India , but after paying my extortionate entrance fee it would be nice for this to be cleaned up . At the ticket office there is a sign showing what is forbidden inside - I checked and made sure nothing I had in my bad was not allowed . Walk 1km , join the queue and get searched - everyone in this process was EXCEPTIONALLY rude . About ten items from by bag were deemed not allowed , small spare things for my camera and a 's elfie stick ( none of this was mentioned on the poster ) . I was told to get out with my options being bin the items , find someone to look after them for me or walk back to the ticket office and use a locker . So walk 1km back dealing with the hassle , then walk back 1km to get to the Taj , because our tickets had been checked already before security we were then told our tickets had been used and we could not go in again ! I had to argue for 10 minutes that we had not even been in yet ! Security check again , I saw many Indian tourists being allowed in with the items that we were prohibited entering with . Inside everyone is harassing you for money - want to go to the toilet ? Despite the big sign that says free for foreigners the staff ask for tips the guards ask for tips the ticket people ask for tips and then going back the locker people ask for tips do not GIVE ANYONE ANYTHING ! After being charged the crazy price of 750 rupees I was not going to give a penny to anyone . If you want to charge tourists so much more then the visitor experience needs to be changed . It sucks , guides harass you , workers harass you , staff are rude and you are sent running about trying to store things that no one tells you you can not take in . It is dirty , it stinks and the ticket is only for one entry . Something needs to change if you want to charge foreigners so much more - perhaps allowing us to enter multiple times ? It would be nice to be able to visit in the afternoon and the morning , or go out to have food and go back in again . Of course you will visit , of course it is stunning - but geeeeesus India , organise it better so we do not feel so ripped off and sort out this racist pricing system !

review_body: The Taj Mahal - So I went this weekend finally to see it because it was my daughters request before leaving India . It reminded me how much I hate that type of sight seeing with the whole tour guide and it made me sick to my stomach the consumerism behind it all . ( Though I am guilty of buying a rug for my new home ) But I would rather bike and run around to visit cities , and I much rather see what mother nature has to offer ( waterfalls , mountains , rivers , etc ) . than man made stuff that have destroyed what was once given to us . Agra , what a mess . One of the seven wonders made me wonder where all that tourist money was going to , because it was certainly not going back to the city , Agra is a terrible dirty poor place , neither was it going back to conserve the reason why the Taj was placed there - because of it is majestic scenery , which is now a dirty river with not much water left in it , and the horrible city smell . Just wondering where this world is going to end if we do not change our ways .

The Taj Mahal itself is a nice monument , although really noth that special . Looks much more majestic and charming on the pictures all over the internet than in reality . Beware of the scammer guides before you enter . We never got one , nor wanted one , but you should know this - this guy , probably with a fake government tourist guide ID , approached us and quoted us with 1200 rs for his services , saying it was a really cheap indian price . We insisted we did not need him and just kept walking and he followed us and his offer was gradually , but quickly going down to 300 rs . Then he finally got it and stopped following us . Now to the other things - just before we got our tickets , they did not want to let us go further because we had small backpacks . They checked the contents and said it was ok and let us go . After we got the ticket at an exorbiant rate of 750 rs per person we had to go through security screening again . We had to put our bags through an xray machine and then they searched them again - taking everything out and inspecting and touching every little item in it . Furthermore , they took some personal belongings without explaining why . Humiliating . Would definitely not go to Agra again .

When your bag is x-rayed the Army checkers will rumage through your bag and pick thing out that they will say are not allowed , i had a portable radio , a torch , my mobile phone charger , a mini tripod for my camera removed from my bag NOT ALLOWED you have a choice now they throw it in the bin at the checking station or you take them back so you can walk back 500m to a locker room where you can pay r30 for then to go in an open shelve till you get back . After waiting in line for 40 minutes to get in at sunrise was made to walk 4 blocks to pay for a locker to put a book and flashlight that was in my backpack in . So everyone with their 3 inch thick guide books are ok , but not a novel to read while waiting in line ? Tour guides there yelled at me to take my shoes off when they already were , I just chose to not waste the shoe covers and so I did not look like every other tourist and then to them obviously was not following the rules . Waste of time and money . Rude staff .

I visited Agra only to visit the Taj Mahal . I had tremendous expectations from this monument as i had read about it in school and how it was the epitome of love , not to mention being classified as one of the 7 wonders of the world . What turned me off initially , was the fact that foreigners are treated differently there , they have to pay 10 times the entry fee that an Indian pays to enter the Taj . This is pure discrimination and that too against people who bring in maximum revenues for the tourism industry in India ! The area around the Taj is quite good and well maintained , but when i got to the actual structure itself , it appeared to be yellowing with age and the ASI were doing some work on restoring the fascade in places where the building appeared to be crumbling . I entered the Taj and was pushed by the security to make a move on , i walked around the monument in a circle , and that was it ! Nothing more to see ! It was a total dampner , apparently people are not allowed on the lower floor of the Taj due to vandalism and the like . It was very disappointing that all i got to see was a few precious stones which were embedded in the marble . The searing heat was kept out and i felt quite cool inside the taj , but nothing else to write home about . The shopping centers around the taj are total rip-offs and should be avoided . Also , the local rickshaw guys try to pull a fast one on you if you look remotely foreign ( or dressed in shorts for that matter ) . All in all , it was a very disappointing visit for me . All i can say is , go there with 0 expectations and you will like the place , if you have any kind of expectation before you visit the taj , you will not like it .

No Doubt it is one of the seven wonders listed . I am only providing my view more from a family outing perspective . we started off from Greater Noida in our car , the Highway is one is the best in India with wide , clean road up to Agra . Once in Agra , proper directions are not provided to reach Taj Mahal . you need to ask a few shopkeepers for direction . Once you reach there , parking is haphazard , you are charged parking fee , but no attendant is there to help you park the car . Taj Mahal in itself is good , actually it looks much more beautiful in pictures than actually when you visit , had to stand in long queue , even to get inside , inside it was littered with polythene , leaves etc . Structure is not well maintained , hardly you can see white stone , it is all yellow . half through children anted to get out , did not like a bit anything about Taj Mahal . Once outside , you only have one restaurant , that is not in good condition , prices are ok , but food quality is bad , you can take your own food or snacks , avoid eating at restaurant .

Traveled to visit the Taj Mahal , but made the mistake of bring a notebook and my bag of pens with me in my small travel bag . Security searched through the entire notebook ( reading each card that was wedged between pages searched through my pen case , completely re-arranging everything . My GoPro mounts were also removed from my bag . When I explained to them that it was something that carried the camera so I would not have to , they explained the tripods were not allowed . I turned and pointed at a woman who had a camera on a STRAP and told them it was the same thing . They refused and asked me to leave and find the government lockers . I was frustrated and pretty frazzled at the newly-disorganized look of my bag and the items that were taken out of my bag , prohibited from entry into the Taj Mahal . This should be posted somewhere - Bring a camera and wallet ONLY ! The Taj Mahal is absolutely beautiful , but this Security Check messed with my desire to even see the Taj by the time I would gotten through Not such an excited traveler anymore , .

About the monument - 1 ) Its pale , cream , maybe yellowish is right color to describe due to pollution and dust in air , very unlike as shown in photos available on internet . 2 ) Parking lot goons , cheat cameramen , stalker tourist guides , footwear thieves , corrupt police personnel , rude & unhelpful staff at the ticketing counter made me swear to never visit Taj Mahal neither go to Uttar Pradesh even . 3 ) Indian govt & local Agra city people are not doing enough effort to protect the rich heritage . 4 ) Unsafe for women , as seen eve-teasing incidents by local youngsters who come inside the complex for free with an excuse for praying in two mosques in the same compound , Its over hyped exaggerated about its beauty due to symbolic reason of love which makes everyone visit it once with their partners . But its first and last for me !

Firstly , regardless of the reviews here , you will visit the place if you are in the area . Enough has been said about the taj . However , the guides really harass you . They will be in your ear all the time . The same with people asking to take photos . And a myriad of other things . They are really intrusive . Foreigners are however spared largely cos they are delivered directly to the gate , from the ticket counter , in electric carts . I guess this comes complementary with the high value ticket . There are agents inside who will nag you though . Also , buy shoe covers if you are going inside . Else you have to take your shoes off approximately 100 meters away from the mausoleum and walk on the cold ( or hot ) slabs . And in winters the fog is bad , you will not be able to see the monument from far , till about noon . Weekends and holidays are really crowded so try and avoid those days . do not buy souvenirs from outside the taj as they are overpriced . There are better monuments in India , honestly . Maybe if the touts were not obtrusive , it would have felt better . And perhaps , we might have enjoyed the monument . But as it stands , we walked away not impressed .

I loved the Taj Mahal . It was grand and majestic and just as beautiful as I had expected it to be . Yet , I am appaled by the fee that foreigners are forced to pay . A foreign adult over the age of 15 years is expected to pay 750 rupees ( approx . $ 15 AUD ) . Yet , a local Indian tourist is only expected to pay 20 rupees ( approx $ 0.40 AUD ) . How can they charge such ridiculous prices between the two groups , based on tour nationality and our skin colour . I am absolutely appaled ! I feel as though we Westerners are being treated with the utmost disrespect and the Indian authorities are scamming us in every single way . We have no choice but to pay - we are suckers to the Indian scam ! Furthermore , after entering the Taj and going through security , I was stopped by one of the police guards , who after checking my backpack , informed me that I could NOT bring my book into the grounds of the Taj . Apparently , only guide books are allowed but not reading books for pleasure . What kind of country is India if they refuse to let foreigners bring in a reading book ? Then , when I was asked to give the books to my guide , and I informed the officer that I did not have a guide , they looked at me blankly as if they assumed that every White foreigner should have a guide . So I was escorted off the grounds and had to dump my reading book in a rubbish bin . Anybody reading this review should be warned that reading books are NOT allowed in the Taj Mahal ( unless it is a guide book ) !

This happened when my Mum and my sister's family went to India and visited Taj Mahal in Dec . 2014 . The Taj Mahal is very famous world heritage and understand that visitors need to go through security checks before enter . My niece ( 8yo ) had small bear and rabbit dolls in her little bag as her travel mates . When she came to security check , the security officer lady opened my niece's little bag , found the little animal toys and said that these are suspicious items and need to confiscate . The officer was not just joking to the kid . She was about to take the toys away from the little girl . My sister told the officer how this little doll is precious for her little girl . Then they finally got the toys back to my niece . When my Mum talked about this to several people including relatives and friends and myself , all said that the small toys could not be suspicious item with bullet or any hazardous things hidden in . But most likely the security officer wanted to put the little bear into her pocket and give to her own child or to entertain herself , or sell to robber's market to earn cash . So ridiculous . Positive thing was my sister's ability to protect her daughter's belongings from such criminal action by rotten security officer . She could get these toys back from the officer . I am sure this is going to be traumatic to the kid even though her Mum could get the toy back . Please be careful when Taj Mahal security officer there is about to take your things away without detailed explanation and if your sense suspect that the greedy officer just want to steal your goods .

Also expected the view to be great but really not worth it . Firstly , it feels like you are going to a border area the way security puts you through 3 checks , armed CRPF accompany you there and bus you back . No cell phones , bags , purses but a full fledged camera will do ! You basically can enter the main gate and that is it ! This after going through all the trouble of getting the tickets and all you see is a hazy silhouette of the Taj .

Do not visit this place until and unless you want yourself to be robbed . Locals over there are ready to loot you . Got fooled by one of the Photographer ( name - Hari Om , contact no - 8410771460 ) . Did a photoshoot for us and delivered CD for pics . Requested him to verify if photos are there in CD . He did not listened to us . And when we get back to Delhi , we found out that CD was corrupted . Called him on his no but he is always ready with his excuses that he will send over the pics through gmail . But nothing has actually happened . In case there are long queues for buying entry ticket at TAJ , then there are GUIDE all over the place , you need to pay them 500 for the 20 ruppee ticket . They have the ticket ready with them ( they have already bought the tickets in bulk ) and they will just accompany to the entry gate . Then they would again go back to the long queues to make money .
Tajmahal in fog looked good . but if you go inside and are not history buff then poor tombs of dead queen will make you cry . And you would wonder why on earth you went to see them .

Being one of the seven wonders of the world and a symbol of the undying love of a husband for his wife , I had a lot of expectations when i visited the Taj Mahal . Unfortunately it was a let down . It was noisy and crowded ( obviously because people flock to be there - Indians and foreigner alike ) . It looked more of a park where people came for picnics . A lot of couples spend their time with each other within the premises hoping to be struck by the arrow of love . There are much better places in Agra that would be rated far above the Taj Mahal . Also , one can not take pictures inside the Taj . Neither can you spend more than 5 secs inside because there is a huge line and the volunteers / guards keeping urging you to move along . On top of that , the tombs of Shah Jahan and Mumtaz Mahal is covered with a outer wall which has a lot of pores . As in , it is not a Hard opaque wall but one can hardly see anything . So i did not see any point in entering the Taj Mahal at all if I could not see the tombs properly . However , on second thoughts , i did visit the taj mahal in the afternoon . Had i visited the place early morning , i am sure i would have given a much better review . Hopefully I would get a chance to visit Taj again in the morning and I shall be back to update my review . Sadly till then , visit Baby Taj - much better experience than The Taj !

review_body: The history and the monument it self is worth admiring . The problem is the people who visit such epic places and treat it as dirt . Empty bottles lying inside the monument , Spit stains , People sleeping , trying to write things on the marble . With Rs 10 set as the entry price for Indians they treat it like any other garden they might visit on a sunday evening leaving debris behind them . Its high time the management takes a strict action on such dirty minded people or Increase the entry to rs 100 and people would start respecting the greatest asset of India . Otherwise for me its a waste of time and especially with rs 750 set for my foreign friends its a absolute rip of . Do not visit it ! you are better of watching it on the net unless the officials take a strict action against the people misusing the heritage of India .

Well , to begin with , the Taj Mahal monumnet itself is really beautiful . But overall management there makes the experience really pathetic . To add to that we reached Taj Mahal on a hot sunny day at 1 pm . Despite being a weekday , there was big & uncontrollable crowd . Everyone was very busy in taking photographs ( instead of admiring Taj's beauty ) . I was expecting Taj Mahal to be a quiet place but I was utterly disappointed . The security is tight there but very little thought is given to tourist management . For example , no thought is given to put some drinking water booths in the big ground which in front of Taj Mahal . No effort is made to shield the tourists from scortching sun . There was a long queue to enter the place . Overall , I felt it was waste of time & money travelling all the way from Delhi to visit Taj Mahal .

Yes the monument is nice , yes I took a lot of photos but people who managed this place are really bad how is it possible for one of the most visited place of the world First , okay 750Rs for foreigners and 20Rs for indians ( no student prices ) but I can understand , even if you are working in India it is 750Rs btw and do not try to explain they do not care . Second things there are a lot of things forbiden in the place but there is no list or board indicating the prohibited items . I think they could manage to put this just next to the check-in but if you are not happy what is the problem , it is the Taj they will always have tourists , so they do not care .

The beauty of the Taj Mahal is spoilt by the numerous guides hounding us at the entry . The entry itself is not well maintained . There is tight screening at the entrance , and if you have to go back to the cloak room to deposit something , the cloak room is a long way from the screening area . review_body: I do not know what it is with local Indians who for some reason think all foreigners have just crawled from under a stone , most of us are not backward at coming forward and when we have prebooked a car / driver to take us to Agra via the expressway do not need any pathetic attempts at being scammed for the already prepaid toll fees , we also do not need a bogus tour guide waiting for us to arrive at the hotel to then tell us that we will not be allowed into the Taj Mahal without a registered guide . The visitors entrance to the Taj Mahal is unkempt and tawdry , the streets are strewn with litter , hawkers and unsavoury characters . TheTaj complex itself is disappointing in that considering it as unesco status , no attempts have been made to repair the gardens let alone the actual monuments , the avenue of thuja's along the canal are in sad state , the fountains do not work properly if at all and the tank is full of algae , the mausoleum was dirty and overcrowded with locals flouting the no photography / do not touch signs while attendants / guards wearily waved them on . If any of my preconceived ideas on what the final resting place of the beloved Princess was , they were shattered on entering it and i was left speechless . Best time to go is very early in the morning , wait outside until it opens . I would have liked to have rated it excellent but since it is badly managed and in a sad state of disrepair it only get 2 stars .

sad to see the world heritage being handled so poorly by our government , No protection from pollution white marble has started getting yellow . Wherever a precious stone has peeled off from embroidery it has been shamelessly filled by white cement . And now they are planning to open Taz mahal 7 days a week to generate more revenue , ?

Upon arrival to west gate was told to pay 30 rupees . After having driver park the car I wanted to eat a lunch I brought with me . No sooner than I started eating than people were knocking on the window wanting to offer me special discounts . My driver even let a guy in the vehicle and he told me he was going to be my guide . I came there for peace and quiet and never achieved it while there . When I went to go into restroom there were 5 guys standing in there and one of them demanded to me that I would pay 5 rupees to use the toilet . I told him he had not right to talk to me that way and I was going to use the restroom . The guys got up acting like they were going to rob me but me being an American and ex military I stared them down . I went to the security guys at the one gate to notify them but they did not act in the least bit interested . I went through my tour as a high value customer with no issues except the tour guides assigned to me wanted to get paid tips for walking with me . I had already done a goggle on the Taj and was aware of all the facts and figures . I am not happy that they charge so much and yet no security exists to protect tourist from the harassing conditions one feels when trying to get there . I walked in 49 centigrade heat rather than have another person bother me but they still harassed me . If asked would I do this again the answer would be HELL NO ! Not worth the aggravation . The ministry of tourism should be ashamed of how they have let things get so out of control at the Taj Mahal .

well , what can I say , beautiful building . BUT , we were immediately surrounded by beggars and children aggressively selling trinkets , which was unpleasant but perhaps to be expected . then when viewing the taj mahal , the sheer mass of people meant that we were quickly marshalled round the tomb by aggressive staff in military uniforms and piercing whistles and out again within perhaps 2-3 minutes . I think we might have gone on a particularly busy day . There were only 3 female toilets which left a lot to be desired . If you must go , hire a driver and a guide who will get you to the head of the queues , and be able to answer questions , give you some history and so on . take your own food and drink and - important ! - toilet roll and hand sanitizer . do not buy photo's or trinkets on the way in . you can judge for yourselves and buy on the way out of you choose .

The Taj Mahal is everything it is made out to be and more . Look at the amazing details ! Beware of people trying to show you where to take a photograph and then asking for money . There are always hundreds of tourists here . But if you want a quiet moment and it is not a Friday , go the mosque to the left of the Taj Mahal - this is a very special place that is rarely included in pictures of the Taj Mahal . There is a similar building to the right but it does not have the same devotional atmosphere . Perhaps because the mosque is still used as a mosque .

review_body: They jam in the tourists . They jam out the tourists . It is operated as a high volume cash creating event for the government . So sad because the Taj itself is beautiful . It is ruined by the overwhelming amount of visitors and amount of people trying to sell you useless services and trinkets .
Never never spend your hard earned rs . 510 ( for Indian , per person ) to see Taj Mahal at night . The army personals also upset to take you there at night .

This may sound like sacrilege , but this was our least favorite experience in India . There is a breathtaking view through an archway as you approach the monument , and we later wished we left it at that . Part of this is due to the overly slick guide we ended up with , and his photographer cohort . They were extremely rude to Indian families , trying to shoo them off benches so we could have photos taken , which we refused to do . We were mortified . We did not mind paying the higher price for tickets , as it is totally fair for Indians to pay less . We did mind being shoehorned into the entry chamber of the Taj . There were guards there , but they had no control whatsoever of the crowds , just jamming them in until you would not have fallen down if you fainted , no joke . One person fell going in because of pushing and shoving . We left the tour at this point . We went on a weekend - try to avoid that because the crowds are bigger then . We cannot speak to the interior of the Taj , so maybe it was worth all that , but not for us . Its exterior is totally stunning to see . Its elegant simplicity is a wonder and the size of it is as impressive as advertised . do not miss Fatehpur Sikri while in Agra - we LOVED it , and would happily have passed up the Taj to spend more time there .

I always thought Taj Mahal would be the best part of our India trip . While the monument is still beautiful , it is so full of tourists and locals trying to get money from you that it is difficult to enjoy anything , specially when you have already seen it a million times in pictures anyway . The highlight of our trip in India turned out to be the city of Jaipur .

You read about the Taj Mahal in loads of travel books , and information given by the Indian government and your expectations are of something not seen anywhere before and so fantastic . Sadly I have been misled . First let me say its a well built temple out of marble and looks good in it is surrounding , inside are to marble coffins but that is all . The gardens are well kept . that is it . Outside of the main gates is filth , depravation and I will treatment of animals on a big scale . After seeing both in such a short distance from each other you have to ask why they spend millions on a pile of marble , and nothing on the surrounding area . St Paul's in Rome , Notre Same in Paris and Buckingham Palace in London are far superior to the Taj . A long journey , for nothing great would never ever think of returning to here . This is an honest review without the rose tinted glasses .

Got in a crowded Saturday . Tickets were difficult to get , there were fake guides all around the place pushing to get easy money . do not listen to them they are a waist of time . The place was so crowded that we got to see a big crowd and behind it the taj mahal . The guards were literally herding .

I really do not understand why this building is so famous . it is pretty , but really nothing spectacular compared to , for example , the Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque in Istanbul , or almost any Roman ruins or major cathedrals in Europe . I expected a lot more from a world site this well-known , and was very disappointed . It felt like a waste of a lot of time and money to get over to there . The preservation really needs some serious work . Also , they need to education visitors about the importance of respecting and not damaging important historic sites . People have chipped away at sections of marble , which was sad to see . There are cracks that needs repairing , and the whole thing did not look like they kept it clean enough . The grounds need some work also . The shrubs looked like someone hacked away at them with an electric saw and the grass is patchy and brown in some spots . For a world site and a place earning so much by charging each foreigner 5x the daily salary of many locals , you would think they could keep things in better shape .

This is an amazingly beautiful place . Only problem is that it is ruined by the overcrowded tourist and the constant scam . Originally being an Indian , visiting this was on my bucket list . I am glad I did it , but I will never come back again .

We went to pick up tickets this evening for visiting the Taj tomorrow - instead of giving us change the man behind the counter repeated lots of the same information three times , handed us over our tickets , and pointed us in the direction of the shoe covers . Had to ask for change and were shortchanged significannotly , finally gave the right change when we requested the specific amount . No attempt at apology , and he seemed very nonplussed - highly suspicious this happens a lot with tired-looking tourists . Beware ! ( obviously the rating above is for ticket desk & not the Taj itself ) !

We were booked for a sunrise tour . Upon arrival we were told the Taj does not open until sunrise . Even though we were there very early and near the front of the line it took over an hour to get through security during which time I was advised that I could not come in as I was carrying contraband . I was escorted to the exit and told I was not allowed in but none was able to tell me why . After ten minutes my partner finally found the guide who got the army to explain that the handle of my camera resembled the shape of a tripod and was not allowed . I was forced to dismantle my camera and remove parts of it to be able to get in . There was no where to leave the camera parts and I was told I could pay a street vender to hold them . Once inside the sun was already above the horizon . Our guide who was considered one of the best proceeded to tell us lies and began making things up when we caught him out . The only bathrooms available incurred a charge and were the most disgusting we visited in a month long tour of india , worse then most gas stations . Overall the experience was one worth forgetting , I would not go back .

I had many problems when I went to the Taj Mahal . I am going to list a few . First of all the people at the Agra Fort lied to us and said we could get money off when we went to the Taj and it is actually the other way around . We asked if this could be fixed when we arrived at the Taj and they did not even consider it . Secondly , they took all of my food away which is fair since they tell you in advance that this is not allowed . As I was waiting to have my belongings taken , another woman was standing next to me and allowed to enter with her food . When I asked why she could enter and that this was not fair , the woman police officer just looked at me and rolled her eyes . Third , When we tried to complain at the main office inside the Taj , we dealt with men who spoke English until they realized we were complaining and then suddenly could not speak English . We were given a BIG complaint book to write in and then shrugged off as well . And finally , While in the Taj I had to get the police because of a group of men who would not stop taking my picture and rubbing their private parts while doing it . When I got the police , the men ran away and then returned from the other side . Overall , the Taj is a beautiful site to see , yes . But the experience in the site and in Agra was horrible .

review_body: We had been travelling for months and really looked forward to visiting the Taj , but it was truly the worst experience we had . Our driver pushed us into having a guide , who tried to push us into having a photographer and taking a whole day guided tour . We had to pay everyone just to leave us alone . Being blonde and white meant I was followed around all the time we were there , and random people took photographs of me without permission . However we did meet some people who were nice , who asked to talk with us and then take a photo . The Taj itself was dirty , pieces of the decoration missing and people visibly hacking pieces out of the walls with knifes . The grounds were a bit better . Overall we had a pretty bad experience , our unlucky day .

Okay , I am not saying the Taj Mahal was terrible . It is always a wonderful opportunity to visit a place you have heard about all of your life . But as a Trip Advisor reviewer , I am warning you not to go inside . The outside is lovely . Inside is like a fun house that is not fun . Small , dark , crowded with nothing to see . If you doubt me , just ask the people at the exit if you should go in . My wife is a bit claustrophobic and I had to comfort her for the circular walk around the dark interior with people crowded cheek to jowl . There is no turning back . Enjoy the grounds and exterior but do not go through the tiny interior . You may also wish to avoid the sunrise visit , which will have you standing in line , in the dark before the gates open , just to wait for the rising sun to strike the Taj . All of that would have been fine except for having to depart for the bus 10 minutes before the morning sunlight ever touched the building . As a photographer , I was really griped that the shot I waited for , crouching in the perfect position to get , was missed by such a short period of time . The sunset photos were better . Skip sunrise unless you have control over the departure time .

Arriving in Agra me and a group of friends made the decision to get stuck right in . Beware outside this fine attraction there is numerous touts / conmen trying to sell you fake entrance tickets etc bypass them get into the legit entrance and pay your 750 rupees entrance fee ( instantly worthwhile to avoid the hassle / racket outside . Once in there the Taj does live up to all expectations . Although if choosing Agra as a holiday destination as a whole i could think of much better places to go .
Too many beggars and hucksters and people preying on tourists with inflated prices . When an Indian comes to NYC and visits the Metropolitan they are not asked an inflated entrance fee why here .

The city of Agra is renowned for the Tajmahal , thanks to the environment friendly and 's ecurity concerned govt . of india , causing much difficulties to the tourist . 1 ) there is a serpentine Que system of about 300mtrs to center the Taj premises , even if no person is present you have to pass thru the serpentine que system for security check , if the security persons does not allow some of the articles you carry you have to come back deposit them in lockers again buy a ticket , again pass thru the serpentine Que system and pass thru the security check . 2 ) there is no provision for drinking water once you enter the Tajmahal-if you forget to carry drinking water you have to come back about one kilometer to procure water after buying water bottles i have to pass thru the que system even though i was having the ticket counterfoil i was forced to buy a fresh ticket again pass thru the que system-security check . 3 ) you are not allowed to reach the tajmahal with footwear you have to deposit the footwear at the faciltiy provided - but the taj mahal becomes so hot by afternoon you can not walk barefeet-solution-go back one kilometer to buy shoe covers at Rs . 10 / per pair-buy a new entry ticketagain pass thru the que system-security check . 4 ) we Indians are forced to travel long distances to reach The Tajmahal foreigners are permitted through short distance to reach the taj mahal . hence my advice is to buy water bottles and shoe covers before entering the Taj mahal . with regards . suman gupta .

The entrance of the Taj Mahal is very expensive for the foreigners and honestly I am not sure it is worth paying this price to visit a tomb . they are trying to get as much money as possible thanks to the reputation of the monument but there is not much to see . I have seen many places much more interesting in India . The only thing I really enjoyed here was the garden , clean of all the garbage you will see everywhere in Agra . BTW , they often confiscate the batteries of the camera during the security check , officially to prevent a kind of attack with the batteries , or more probably to sell them a bit further They will also ask you to pay to take yours shoes back , when it is written above their head . do not pay .

review_body: The Taj is worthy to see once in a lifetime , but too much noise is made about it . We did not felt the great emotion some guides say it provides . We were too busy trying to walk away from the dozens of people harassing us outside , and too busy being taken in picture inside because we are european . We came at dawn , and did not see much of the light-changing colors it is supposed to have , .

I have spend a month in India in various places and this was by far the most commercial . WOW - such a big palace ! All the Westeners got excited - fine . But hardly any indian , well other than sales people . They were just terrible . Dragging you into their stores buy this , hey my friend , hey - nice tshirt - where did you get it - can I try it on , just to make you come into their store . If you think you will go and spend an hour with an absolute monumental place - think twice . This is a shopping mole .

Like many I have been made believe that the Taj Mahal is the best monument in India . But to my surprise it has been a big disappointment . I was all geared up to visit the Taj after a weeklong planning and route mapping . I was prepared to drive all the way from Delhi to Agra on the bumpy road only to get a glimpse of the mesmerizing Taj Mahal . Unfortunately after all the hardship was not worth the efforts . Parking is 2kms away from the entry gate . I was advised to take the east gate for a quick access by one of the guides at the Agra fort . After crossing a maze I have managed to get myself to the east gate . Struggled for about 30minutes to manage a parking bay . Then when I started to walk towards the monument plenty of tongawalas or the Auto rickshaw drivers pounced on me to drive me to the gate . Believe me that is at 10times the price for the distance . Again to my surprise the vehicle was only to cover half the distance only . I continued walking towards the monument for another kilometer and found myself in the queue as long as Great Wall of China . Sad sad sad , to top it up was the rude behavior of the security force at the monument . They do not care if its women , children or elderly people , they have only learnt the language of PUSH . After a 45minute long wait I managed to pass through the security check . Then came the next hurdle to make my way to the monument . People were crazy taking pictures of the monument . The only saving grace was the magnificent white marble monument shining in the bright sun . But it looked no different in the pictures and videos available in the books and online . Now comes the turn of the photographers to suck your book to click a picture , they do not spare you unless they do not take your picture . I was made to take my shoes off and made to walk bare foot on the hot marble as hot as frying pan . I had tears in my eyes and cursed myself to have taken this decision to visit Taj . The queue was too long and I was made to go round the monument thrice before I could enter the tomb . Here comes the worse of all , the security gaurd at the entrance of the tomb started to push hundreds of people physically into the center hall and then pushed out without even getting an opportunity to take a glimpse of the toms of Shah Jahan and Mumtaz Mahal . that is it this washed all my love for this monument and I left the city of Agra with great disappointment and just getting out of the traumatic experience . My advice to fellow visitor would be to visit Taj Mahal during week day and off vacation timings . You may still get an opportunity to take a careful look at India's Pride .

They sell the tickets in two denominations . 20Rs for Indians and 150 for foreigners . That is where the discrimination starts . For Indians , they make you walk more than 5 times as much as foreigners around the Taj before they allow you to go in . Once inside , they again have go around routes for Indians and straight ones for the so called High Value tickets . Idiots , I do not know of one other place in the world where natives are discriminated !

With the charge of 750 rupees for foreigners , the least they can do is to to keep the place clean , especially the Taj Mahal itself . it is too dusty and defiantly takes off a lot from the impression of it , .

I was blessed to have visited the Taj Mahal 30 years ago . That was an amazing experience - we spent the entire day & enjoyed the Taj during the different lighting effects of the day through the sunset & moonrise . A very unhurried and restful experience . I visited again in February 2013 . Now the Taj is overrun with monkeys , people shoving and guards whistling . Also parts that were open previously are now closed . Yes . The story and the craftsmanship are indeed amazing . However , as far as enjoying a sublime experience is concerned - not so much . Note - It does help to visit on a sunny day if you can . The Sunlight does accentuate the beauty of the architecture . I am ever so grateful for that first visit in 1983 .

Security is a big issue now , and masses of locals flock to the place these days , as they pay only a fraction to enter compared to foreigners . Its almost too crowded to take pictures with humans in the shot . The reflective pools were either empty or grubby , and the town of Agra is a total dusty dirty mess . I preferred the Taj it back in the 60's , no locals visiting , no crowds , and no entry fee . Yeh !

Yes , it is something that you should see once in your lifetime - but really only to say you have done it . do not expect too much from this much talked about monument . When we visited , there was a throng of people and we were literally pushed inside with the crowd and back out again ! We did not get a chance to look around inside properly at all . Go see it , but keep your expectations to the minimum , .

Everybody talks about how marvelous is the Taj Mahal , for that reason I decided to visited it when I passed by Agra . My guide and the locals suggested to visit it in the early morning to see the sunrise reflected on the building , so for that reason the next morning I leave my hotel at 6:30 am but the problem was the fog ! Was like to be in an horror movie coz I was not able to see where I was walking by . With luck I arrived to the queue and payed a 20 euro 's fee to get in to the building , the place was officially opened by 7:30 and was very cold , when finally I get in was impossible to see the Taj at all , it was completely covered by the fog ! I wait until 10 am and finally I could see something but not to have a proper view and that was very disappointing . So before you go plz verify which one is the best season to visit the place . Another important thing to mention is on the net there is a company who develops a sw you can download on your phone and offer you a guided tour so you do not need anymore a guide to make your visit . This company is the same one who develop the audio tour's for different city sights and I must say is very , very good . The product is called Audio Compass . If the day is clear ask your guide carry you by the side of the Jamuna River where you can see the Taj , is a very nice view too . Good luck !

I can not say that Taj Mahal is ugly because I would lie but I can say that there are other palaces that are better than it . For example the Golden Temple . This has to become one of the world wonders . Then , Taj Mahal is not a peacuful place . It has become so crowded that you cannot feel that amazing sensation of peace and purification . Moreover , you have to pay 750rupiees ( note - Indian people only 50 rupiees ) to admire it and enter inside . it is so little inside and you have to run away because it is not allowed to stop and watch the tomb . It has been a disappointment .

No iPhones , no light , not allowed on the grounds . Rip off . Go during the day and enjoy . You will be searched , probed , and prodded . They have no light except the flashlights of the guards . No shops open . All together a really bad idea . Not sure how they even get to sell a ticket except to ignorant tourists like me .

Go during the day when I would rate it four stars and forget the night hype . We paid Rs . 750 for the night visit . It took ages to go through security , all our bags were taken off us , even the pens in our pocket . All that can be taken through is money , still camera and passport . you will need to put the rest in a locker for collection on your return . As for the Taj Mahal itself , its not flood lit so even in a full moon you can hardly see it . You can only enter just through the gateway on a platform so you are a long way away from the actual monument . Make sure you plan your moon light visit , otherwise , like us , the moon will be the opposite side of the sky to the Taj so will not even get into the picture ( that is if you have learned how to operate your camera's manual settings otherwise you will just get a blank screen ) .

Not worth walking through the crowds , the filth , and the stench . I had a headache when I came back . We had high priced tickets which typically should have had shorter lines , but the guards were unable to manage the crowds . There were shoe covers strewn all over the floor , and we got jostled through the tour . The monument is small , and not that impressive compared to others in Istanbul and other parts of the world, It is unlit , and poorly maintained .

review_body: On my last day in India my girlfriend and I decide to hire a car and go all the way to Agra from Delhi . From the moment we landed in the country to that point there ha been nothing but praise for the Taj Mahal . Well to make a long story short it was not worth the 5 + hour car trip , tickets to get in or the guide we for some reason were required to have . Please do not waste any time seeing this the greatest letdowns ever .

The Taj mahal is obviously the most beautiful structure one can see in their lifetime . But , Agra is simply put a filthy town . One would imagine that the city which attracts so many tourists would do something to improve the state the city is in . That is still pardonable . But the way the Taj Mahal is run is simply appalling . There is no structure .
